author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
I'm scared of taking money because I heard I can get fired. 

This was a question, amongst MANY that were asked this weekend at a pickleball mixer for the startup community. 

Let's address it head on. Yes, as investors, we design a host of protections and provisions in the definitive documents to safeguard our investment. 

No, we REALLY don't want to run your company. 

A lot of us on the VC end have had operational careers, building across corporates/startups. 

We're here to invest in the next generation of growing companies.

Firing a Founder typically happens in very very extreme scenarios, namely:

1. Ethics violations: Theft, embezzlement, personal enrichment at company expense, gross misconduct etc

The above doesn't leave much room for other solutions. 

2. Co-founder conflict: If there's unresolvable Co-Founder conflict in terms of direction of the company, then investors sometimes have to step in, along with external mediators/guides, to find a solution. This can lead to one of the dissenting Founders parting ways

3. Performance (or lack of): This is a much much rarer case, with investors usually supporting by bringing in talent to support the Founders. If it can't be fixed, then this could lead to an exit

4. Mega growth: Sometimes, the company grows faster than the Founders can keep up. In these cases, it's usually an amicable discussion, since the Founders are some of the largest shareholders. 

Decisions taken here are collaborative, to maximize the returns for all shareholders.

I've covered the most common scenarios I've seen across 13 years of investing and building, chime in with anything I've missed! 

#vc #venturecapital #startups

comments.Headline: TMH | ISB | NISM i DeRisk Healthcare Investments for founders & funders, enabling profitable exits & scaled returns.
comments.Comment: IMHO the problem stems from a lack of understanding what a founder is & knowing when to let go- one of the hardest things ever. I very often come across folks who do not understand the distinction between the company and self. Ask them to put up a CEO who is not on the company board & comes the resistance but why? The founder very often thinks they & the company are one & the same. It's very hard to get this mindset out of their psyche to try & convince them that given the fact that they themselves are the largest shareholders it will be in their best interests to see independent governance that does what's best for the company. It is at this point where I see the conflict growing- what may be best for the company may not be the best for the founder.  I for instance am not on the board of directors for my own company, I understand my limitations & i best live it to wiser heads to take operational & financial decisions. I chart the board in the right direction with nudges but after that it's completely their call, they are collectively the best people to act on without any biases that I may have. And I have seen ample proof that's the best way to grow, when you have clear insights no biases and clear goals.

text:
Do you want to join Devarsh and I in the writers' room of The Founder & The Funder?

Over the past few days Devarsh and I have received some really lovely comments and love, as well as some really great insights for future episodes. 

Since we are building TF&TF for the community, we are looking for the following folks to join us in the writers' room (tomorrow evening) as we brainstorm the next few episodes of TF&TF:

1. 2 startup founders (Bombay Founders' Club Members get preference)
2. 2 folks from the VC space
3. 1 person who is neither a founder nor a VC but has a demonstrated interest in startups and the things we talk about.

If you are interested and can join us tomorrow evening post 7pm (either physically and virtually work with us), just comment TF&TF, and we'll reach out to you if we'd like to have you on board.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
We spend 1/3rd of our lives sleeping. 8 hours a day (ideally!). We SHOULD invest in the best mattress money can buy! This is exactly what Priyanka and Harshil (Founders of The Sleep Company) have built a stellar company around.

Having met during their IIM Calcutta days, they married, then followed different professional paths, with Priyanka climbing the corporate ladder to a ‚Çπ1cr+ package with P&G, having managed the P&Ls for brands like Ariel, Tide and Pampers across India, cementing her understanding of retail and distribution and Harshil joined his family business, exporting engineered products globally, giving him a strong grounding in manufacturing and operations.

Post Priyanka giving birth, she suffered severe post partum pain, with no mattress being able to solve the sleep problem. 

She brainstormed with Harshil, and together they engaged Dr Tripathi, a retired DRDO material scientist with 35+ years of experience, to build the best mattress possible. 

After nearly 2 years of R&D (and ‚Çπ1.5 crore of personal savings used), they created their patented SmartGRID technology. 

When they went to market, with a ‚Çπ29,900 mattress (average indian prices at the time were ~‚Çπ10k), even Amazon reps were uncertain this would work.

Retailers blatantly rejected their attempts to place products, asking how much margin they'd get and how long the credit period was, instead of qualitative questions on the product.

From those early hurdles, they've built a business that's close to ~‚Çπ700cr ARR today, with a VERY controlled ~‚Çπ40cr EBIDTA loss.

They've also built across new verticals. I'm a happy user of their standing desk, and am contemplating their work chair since I've seen a LOT of friends using it.

My one observation. As you grow, operational controls tend to get weaker, and this MAKES (or breaks) businesses. 

When I ordered my desk, it was damaged in transit. The team were prompt on sending me a replacement, which was the wrong size. Eventually, the right size was delivered.

However, both the perfectly good wrong sized desk, and the scratched one, are still stuck in my apartment, with no one picking them up despite several messages.

You've built a really good business, tighten the operational controls and it's bound to be great!

#venturecapital #startup #founders

comments.Headline: 3rdEngr/2nd Asst Engr| Founder @ NANDIX | Marine Engineer | Building India‚Äôs First Autonomous Retail Intelligence Engine | Making Retail Self-Driving Engineer | Adaptive Problem Solver
comments.Comment:
Amazing journey and an even more impressive category creation. One thought that may unlock a new revenue stream...

In Tier-2 and Tier-3 India, a large percentage of households don‚Äôt use standard bed sizes they either buy custom cots or get them made by local carpenters. This often creates a psychological friction for premium mattress buyers because they feel 'standard' mattresses may not perfectly fit.

If The Sleep Company introduced a "Custom fit Program" ..where a visit / measurement support / or a ‚Çπxxx voucher for local cot resizing is bundled with the mattress purchase it eliminates this barrier completely.

author/headline: Building the Present and Future of Indian Sports @Elev8 India | Founder | Revolutionising How India Plays, Competes and Grows
text:
Some events take months to plan, but the most magical ones happen within 48 hours, when the right folks and the right energy collide.

This Saturday was exactly that.

I had the chance to attend a very special screening of ‚ÄúThe Founder and The Funder‚Äù a super cool concept created by my friends Avik and Devarsh (with the Bombay Founders' Club). A fresh take on how builders and backers see each other today and how the harsh realities actually are. The kind of folks that were here at the screening and the energy, it was surreal. 

Right after that,  we hosted something I will remember for a long time. More than 130 founders, investors and creators came together for the ‚ÄúPickle and Pitch After Party‚Äù that I co-hosted with Arjun Bhai, Avik and Devarsh. This was after Arjun Bhai had already spent almost 12+ hours doing back-to-back founder sessions at the ‚ÄúPickle and Pitch - Edition 2.0‚Äù. 

The energy was so vibrant. Nikunj Biyani from SuperYou, Parul Gulati (of Nish Hair), my brother Tanishq Mahendru from Courtly, Mirang Manek, Kushal Bhavsar, Priyanshi Chokshi, Aanirban Ghosh, Yash Gawde, Yash Shah and many more joined us on the pickleball court.

No judgement, No pressure and No boring pitches!! 
Just a rare space, where the ecosystem dropped the suits and picked up paddles.

Massive gratitude to GoKwik, Salad Days, Red Bull and Franklin Sports with their X-40 balls for powering the vibe.

We‚Äôve co-hosted many great mixers together over the past few months, yet what made this night special was not the size of the crowd. It was the speed of execution. Arjun Bhai called me and said ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do this‚Äù and the founder in me switched on and within a day, we pulled together one of the most curated groups.

People left with tired legs, buzzing minds and connections that will outlast most pitch decks.

This is what happens when community becomes the fuel.
This is what happens when founders rally together without an agenda.
This is what happens when sport becomes the bridge for meaningful conversations.

Onwards and upwards!! 

Elev8 India Manish Rao 

#pickleball #investors #founders #startups #mixer #picklenpitch #mumbai #india #sports

text:
Ever wonder why the Best Restaurants in the World list bears the same name as a car tyre company? 

It's because they're the same people! 

In 1900, brothers Andre and Edouard Michelin created a free guide book for motorists, including restaurants and hotels, to increase travel, and consequently tyre sales. 

By 1920, the guide became a paid publication, and the brothers hired the first Anonymous inspectors.

By 1933, the famous 3 stars had been firmly put into place, representing:

1 Star: Very good in it's category 
2 Star: Worth a special detour
3 Star: Exceptional enough to be worth the entire journey

Post WWII, the guide resumed in full force, today looked at as one of the most coveted honours in hospitality. 

All created by two enterprising brothers, to sell more car tyres.

#vc #startups #growthhacks

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's Rant day, therefore it's Friday.

Today isn't a traditional rant. 

This week, a lot of Founders asked me what goes into a successful outcome. 

I started with 'Assuming you're an expert in your industry, or building things'.....

Reasons for the above? It's f***ing hard to build something from nothing. 

Things that help? 

1.  Knowing the problem you're solving, and the industry, inside out. Usually takes a LOT of time. 

2. Knowing how to build things. With all due respect to folks who have built, and failed, if you've built and succeeded (sold/IPOd) those lessons are different.

So I've come up with my four points, assuming you know your industry, problem and customer needs;

A. Customers: Pick up the phone and call your ex-colleagues to use you, find new ones, whatever, can you get people to pay you for your solution? 

B. Team: Can you attract the right folks to help you build? BIG make or break indicator. When I'm looking at companies for a funding round, if they know the gaps in their team, and know who they want to hire with that $$$, big green flag

C. Grit: Can you ride the bad times? The times when there's no money in the bank and everything looks BLEAK

D. Luck: Every awesome entrepreneur I've had the privilege to meet acknowledges this. You can do EVERYTHING right, sometimes it's down to luck

#vc #venturecapital #startups

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's tiring!!! When I first started writing, it was inspired by a challenge with a couple of friends Reuben Noronha and Pranjal Kalra .

Learning from my brother Arjun Vaidya , it started becoming a lot more natural.

Over time, I've got reactions from 'why are you spamming us' to 'can you take this post down'.

The former, I learnt to ignore. 

The latter told me that there's actually a bunch of folks who care about what's being written, which adds a whole new level of fear/thought/double check on anything I'd put out. 

Today, at a lovely event courtesy Mohit Gulati (possibly more outspoken than I can be!) , I realized it's about sharing things that most people don't want to share in public. 

The hidden thoughts, the layers of decision making that happen behind closed doors. 

It's been an awesome ride,  here's to many more! 

#vc #venturecapital #writing

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Podcast Alert: Yes, I'm finally starting one, having met the ideal Founder to kick it off with, Devarsh Saraf .

A recovering lawyer, he spent time building a legaltech platform to make great legal advice cheaper and more accessible (didn't play well with Powers That Be).

During the journey, he felt the stress, loneliness and lack of guidance or a playbook that most Founders go through, which led him to start Bombay Founders' Club .

Over many sessions with other Founder friends, we realised the topics covered (and SOME of the Bulls*** we spouted) would be relevant to more people. 

Hence The Founder & The Funder was born. 

We're hosting a small viewing party on Saturday in Bombay, hit us up with TF&TF in the comments for an invite (very limited).

PS: I usually avoid this commenty thing but it's a surprisingly efficient way to manage this guest invite concept

#vc #venturecapital #founders

author/headline: Building Bombay Founders Club
text:
Anyone who knows me knows how much I talk about social capital. 

It's the underlying philosophy with which we are building Bombay Founders' Club. 

Here's an illustration of the power of social capital in practice. 

Over a year and a half ago, I had the privilege of bumping into Pratik Gupta - this was when I had just started off building BFC and was looking for mentors in marketing. 

A call and a few WhatsApp messages later we found ourselves at The Quorum where he told me his life journey over a sif-on-the-rocks and I was mesmerised. 

He happened to introduce me to one of his co-founders Arjit Johri in his amazing venture in the pickle paddle space - Serve Society | A Movement Collective. (This has now become a usual hangout and arguably the best courts in Mumbai.)

Arjit happened to invite me to the launch of Harajuku Tokyo Cafe in Mumbai a few months later, where I bumped into the magnanimous Avik Ashar. 

This Saturday, on the 29th of November, Avik and I will be hosting founders and investors for a private screening of the first ever episode of "The Founder & The Funder" - a podcast where someone in the VC space (Avik) and a founder building for founders (yours truly) talk about everything startups - from co-founder conflicts, that oversmart VC analyst and being a good boss. 

We are opening up a limited number of invites (lucky draw) to non-invitees and non-BFC members for this Saturday - do comment TF&TF if you'd like to put your name in the hat!

#podcast #VC #founders

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Founder: "I'm here to raise 4 crores"
VC: "Why don't you take 50 crores?

Founder: "What am I going to do with this money? I don't have a plan for it? 
VC: "Well, we start by making your product free!! Then (missing step) and MAGIC!

Founder: "What's the missing step?"
VC: "Look do you want the money or not?"

The above reads like a script from Silicon Valley (the TV show!) or a comedy skit.

Those conversations really happened for many years across India (and global) VC. 

With a dangerous trend towards 'mega' funds, allocators of capital are effectively creating funds that are fundamentally impossible to return. 

In attempts to generate the monstrous exits needed, these kind of conversations were commonplace.

Be free, scale, burn baby burn. 

Founders who fell into this trap quickly built bloated businesses that couldn't survive without a regular injection of cash, basically money junkies.

Today is a saner day, thankfully, but the mega fund problem still exists, so do those cheques. 

Raise what you need (with a decent safety buffer).

Or get ready to ride a rocket that has no sanity and a VERY large chance to blow

#vc #venturecapital #fundraising

comments.Headline: XLRI ‚Äô25 | Co-Founder Hintech Energy | CUSAT'21
comments.Comment:
This whole ‚Äúburn for fun‚Äù culture got normalised because valuations stopped being tied to business fundamentals and started selling future possibility ‚Äî the promise of ‚Äúeventually‚Äù hitting EBITDA positivity somewhere in the infinite future.

The strange part is how the entire engine runs on vanity metrics like Active Users and Revenue per User, even when the product is free or priced so low that profitability becomes mathematically impossible. But the story sells, rounds keep coming, and post-money valuations keep skyrocketing.

And here‚Äôs the kicker ‚Äî with every new round, earlier investors still make money on paper. So if customers get the product free, founders get the capital, and VCs keep marking up their books‚Ä¶ who‚Äôs really complaining?

It becomes a perfect win-win loop ‚Äî until the day the music stops.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
it's Rant day, therefore it's Friday. I'm picking a painful topic, called DPI.

Fancy term for 'how much money gent you given back as a fund' 

This is CRITICAL for anybody touching the PE / VC space.

Simply put, it's how much money we have given back to investors in our funds.

Globally, as well as domesticly, there's been a reassessment of Alternatives as an asset class

Why this matters? If funds don't make a great investment case, the Institutions and Family Offices around the world that have trusted us with capital, will stop doing so....

This has MAJOR repercussions for anyone associated with Funded companies.

Having raised funds for the last 7 months, I can tell you, with NO uncertainty, that folks who would give us money are thinking very deeply about the why.

Indian public markets have been returning comparatively similar or better returns. 

The top 10% of VC has performed very well, but the median has just about returned 1x of capital, after TEN years.

For Founders, it's important to look at the global resets and plan accordingly. The myth that USA has friendly patient high risk capital? Poof, those days are done (see link in comments).

We're firmly entering a World where building towards a real business, profits and an exit are crucial. 

#vc #venturecapital #founders

comments.Headline: Building Bombay Founders Club
comments.Comment:
In India‚Äôs current listed-equity boom, I‚Äôm seeing more and more family offices treat VC as a ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù ‚Äì or worse, a bad asset class.

That‚Äôs dangerous myopia.

If LPs only chase liquid, listed upside, who funds the next wave of Indian category-creators before they¬†become¬†listed giants?

If we‚Äôre serious about India‚Äôs innovation story, we need to make early-stage risk capital structurally attractive:
- Tax incentives / pass-through benefits¬†for LPs backing regulated VC funds
- Clearer, faster regulations¬†around AIFs and exits
- A coordinated push from¬†Indian Venture and Alternate Capital Association (IVCA) + founder-led associations¬†to get this on the policy agenda

Otherwise, we drift toward a world where early-stage founders are told:
‚ÄúBootstrap, take debt, or don‚Äôt build.‚Äù

That‚Äôs not how you build the next generation of Indian unicorns ‚Äî that‚Äôs how you miss them.

One of the best feelings as an investor is when your portfolio Founders know they can call you at anytime (when urgent), and openly share the Best and Worst news.

This week, just had a call where a SUPERB portco Founder called out of the blue, with one of the best problems I've heard (too many choices). 

What hits even stronger is when a Founder, who didn't let you into their round (too late!) comes to you as a sounding board, which ALSO happened this week (different folks)

I'm in the investing space for the next 30+ years (liver permitting), and these relationships are ones that I hope to compound.

#venturecapital #founders #happy

text:
There are three things I hope this year's startup IPO fever teaches all of us. 

1. It takes TIME to build a resilient business. 

Behind all these 1000s of crores is years and years of work, 2008 for Lenskart, 2009 for PineLabs (payments, company started in 1998).

Overnight successes are very very rare, and usually accompany overnight falls

2. The market is the ultimate judge

3. That's how long it takes for ESOPs to really matter. Factor them into your life but don't build dreams on them

#venturecapital #startups

text:
At Riverwalk Holdings, we observed early signs of a fundamental shift in how India chooses to live.

Young professionals and students are increasingly gravitating toward flexible, service-led, community-centric living rather than traditional rentals. The old model, defined by rules like ‚Äúno bachelors‚Äù or restrictions on food, no longer aligns with modern lifestyles.

This shift is fueling the rise of the co-living sector, projected to grow at ~40% CAGR through 2030, with the premium segment (‚Çπ20,000+/month) expanding the fastest as aspirations and incomes rise.

While early players focused on rapid scale and adding supply, we believe the next leaders in this space will differentiate through service quality, real estate excellence, and an exceptional customer experience.

With this thesis, we‚Äôre excited to announce our investment in Tribe Stays‚Äô $2.8M seed round alongside our friends at Artha Venture Partners. 

Satveer Jai Sumer Avik Keshav Ali Abhishek

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
There's a constant stream of messages from folks building SMEs chasing venture funding, which is an absolute mismatch in type of capital required. 

India is a very underserved MSME/SME credit market, due to lack of collateral, credit history and high perceived risk from traditional lenders. 

Estimates vary but broadly agree that  47-60% of credit needs from small businesses go unmet.

That's why I love businesses that can enable productive access to credit for businesses, a great example being Aerem , accelerating the adoption of rooftop solar across the country.

Key levers to success: 

- Understand the value unlocked through credit, whether it's reducing blended power cost (in Aerems example) or improving trade credit terms 

- Build non-financial checks, market history, reputation, length of employee tenure etc

- Develop strong non transactional relationships with the borrowers

#venturecapital #fintech #lending

comments.Headline: Technology Enthusiast | IT Enterprise Solutions | Business Consulting | Views on LinkedIn are ‚ÄúPersonal Views‚Äù
comments.Comment:
Avik Ashar No doubt that US Big Techs or US Marketing dominates the world. 

I have a slightly different perspective.
Our brains are affected by #AmFluEnza and we are conditioned to think within those patterns they have established and normalized.
Because we are living in America or an "American market", we think that's inspiring.

Prof Philip Kotler's books are considered benchmark for marketing. 
He often talks about the 4Ps of Marketing, and recently he has given 6Ps lecture. 
Purpose, People, Partners, Peace, Planet, and Prosperity.¬†

The way Peace and Prosperity is interpreted in US is very different from many countries. 

Their case studies work well there, but how each geography is significantly different is often unsolved by them. 

Some of their big companies such as Ford, Harley and GM entered and miserably failed in the Indian market, while Japanese and Korean teams of Suzuki, Honda, Toyota Hyundai and Kia succeeded. 

If you break the pattern, like the Japanese and Korean do, there are limitless possibilities.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's too early for us. We don't invest at that stage. We come in at growth. Series A, B , C..... L M N O P

I keep seeing Founders in my network bump up against this and get frustrated beyond belief. 

Sharing a few (real) reasons why this comes up:

1. Funds operate on Mandates. When we raise money from investors, it's with the promise that we will invest in X type of company, at Y stage.

Asking us to bend that rule is asking us to BREAK OUR PROMISE to our investors. This can get us fired and sued.

2. We usually write some or most of this mandate on our website, social media channels, LinkedIn bios etc. Go through those, saves a lot of time and pain

3. Riverwalk Holdings (insert any fund name) is a Fund Manager. Within this, we run different Funds. Our first fund focused on Seed-Series A. Our second fund now focuses on Series B. This would be similar-ish across other funds, with tweaks in stage, sector allocation etc happening.

It's important to read the most recent news, instead of pointing out at one old article or website link that says 'Seed to Series B'.

4. Different folks, different strokes. You're pre-revenue, going to a fund that doesn't do pre-revenue as a rule. This is going to lead to failure. 

If you put petrol in a diesel car, do you expect it to move? Same example.

5. Sectoral exposure/fit. You might not fit into the sector focus of the Fund, or they are overexposed in a sector. This is harder to suss out, but once again, biggest cues are the Fund's most recent media.

We're on the lookout too, and we post what we look for.

The above should help streamline fundraising while minimizing pain.

Oh and the final reason? It's just a polite no.

#venturecapital #fundraising #founders

comments.Headline: Investment Banking | Private Wealth | Arambh Ventures
comments.Comment:
Wage gaps - that forces people towards such urban centers. In mumbai itself - the wage gap between Nariman Point and Andheri is large, and even larger between Andheri and Vasai - Virar. This is just a distance of 30 - 40 kms for each pair. It is because the old money is concentrated in such centers, and as far as I understand - tax incentives won't cut it for them. The ecosystem is anchored to this wealth. And to change the urban density - this money needs to move out. So called real estate mafias - they have been developing distance suburbs of Mumbai for almost 2 decades now.

Still, Mumbai has done a much better job in the last 10-15 years in bridging this gap, and a lot of large offices have moved to suburbs from south bombay. And considering Navi Mumbai was set up to ease the burden on Mumbai - it's limited success makes the transition look very slow and virtually ineffective.

This wage gap looks particularly painful in the context of the rising ambition of the young population, and thus the large migration towards mega urban centers. Bridge the gap, and most likely people will stay out of the mega urban centers. That needs something much more than just government incentives.

This is the right conversation to be having, Avik. The strain on the metros is at a breaking point.
It reminds me of a solution Javed Akhtar once proposed. He said the government's immediate focus should be on building entirely new, planned cities to de-burden the current ones.
His witty punchline was, "...and they can rename them whatever they like to suit their political agenda."

Jokes aside, his core point is powerful. Your suggestion for incentives is probably right, but maybe applying them to purpose-built new cities is the only truly scalable fix.

comments.Headline: VC @ Hero - Investment Office
comments.Comment:
The real estate mafia will not let that happen. Population concentration is good for their capital gains. The most disappointing thing is how we were not able to transition to WFH / hybrid setups at any meaningful scale even after covid forced this experiment on the world. The scale of impact that this simple move could have had on pollution, traffic, real estate prices and crude import dependence while having near-zero associated capex is something that no amount of infrastructure building (even if it was to keep pace with the demand, in a fantasy world) can ever hope to achieve.

India's TFR is already below replacement levels, so on an average, the only way tier-1 real estate prices can grow faster than inflation is for the population to continue concentrating around existing centers.

comments.Headline: Marketing Leader | ISB | Driving Growth Across Luxury retail, BFSI & D2C | Brand + Performance | CRM | Digital First Leader
comments.Comment:
Tax breaks alone won‚Äôt cut it. What really needs to happen is ecosystem design. Smaller cities probably need three things before talent and companies move:
a.) World-class digital and physical infrastructure: stable internet, reliable power, efficient intra-city transport.
b.) Anchor institutions: universities, startups, and one or two super large employers that attract ancillary businesses.
c.) Cultural capital: schools, healthcare, art, cafes, housing - the softer parts of urban life that make people want to stay.

Once that foundation is built, economic gravity will do the rest. Otherwise, every ‚Äúnew hub‚Äù just becomes another expensive metro in five years.
comments.processed_comment: tax breaks alone wont cut it what really needs to happen is ecosystem design smaller cities probably need three things before talent and companies move a worldclass digital and physical infrastructure stable internet reliable power efficient intracity transport b anchor institutions universities startups and one or two super large employers that attract ancillary businesses c cultural capital schools healthcare art cafes housing the softer parts of urban life that make people want to stay once that foundation is built economic gravity will do the rest otherwise every new hub just becomes another expensive metro in five years

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Lenskart's IPO. Love em, hate em or indifferent, odds are you've heard a hundred opinions. 

Overvalued, bigger than the Indian eyewear market, making fools of the public, these are all terms being bandied around.

Before I unpack my thoughts, I'll go back to the original motto of Value Investing (started by Benjamin Graham, best seen in play by Warren Buffett).

Value Investing is buying into an asset that you feel is intrinsically undervalued/priced.

It's notionally what we follow as VCs, except we're valuing the FUTURE POTENTIAL of the business. 

Similarly, yes, loss making / nominally profitable startups have been allowed to list, which is a sign of a maturing stock market trusting the public to make their own decisions. 

Eternal has given about 175% returns in two years, Ixigo 61% in 1.5 years, Nykaa -33% in 4 years, which tells me clearly that the 2021 madness was still in the air when Nykaa IPOd.

What I focus on at an experiential and fundamental level is: 

- my parents only buy from Lenskart, loving the store experience

- economies of scale on production are immense

- foreign markets have been tapped well, local friends in Singapore, Japan and Dubai have made the switch and share word-of-mouth about the pricing, as well as free fix guarantee

- stellar team in place 

- India's stock market is generally overvalued, but that's not changing because of capital controls

So, good deal at today's numbers? Probably no, but it's a stock I'm happy to hold as it grows into the number. 

#venturecapital #ipo #lenskart

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's Friday so it's Rant Time: AI is table stakes today. 

If, as a founder/team leader, you aren't spending a good part of your time and thought bandwidth (20% at least) into using it, you've lost the race. 

If, as employees, across the board and age bracket, if you aren't figuring out ways to improve your work, from speed to quality of output, with AI? It's walk the plank time. 

Global AI companies have recognised the potential in India, with huge free token issuances, country specific pricing and great partnerships.

OpenAI found 399 rupees to be a sweet spot for their GO plan, giving enhanced features compared to free including image generation, for around what folks pay for a Netflix subscription or monthly phone bill.

Perplexity went a level deeper and partnered with Airtel, offering a year's FREE Pro plan to all Airtel customers, a brilliant way to get people hooked. 

Anyone building financial models should be jumping headfirst into Claude (though MUST double check the work).

I've already seen the gaps in my knowledge, with Founder friends s decade younger showing me how to write better prompts and customise responses. 

Not using these tools is like tying your legs together before competing in a marathon. 

#venturecapital #ai #founders #startups

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
JUST SAY NO! It's not Friday but here's a mini rant anyway. 

Humans are bad at saying two things, Yes and No. 

There's a ton of research around this, I'm simplifying it into a few reasons:

- We (mostly) want to be liked. Saying No hurts this.
- Saying either Yes or No closes a door. Usually saying Yes to A, is implicitly saying No to B opportunity. Once again, we shy away from losing B
- We hope that by saying nothing or dragging it out, the decision will resolve itself (or stop following up) and that's the end of it

I've faced this across three phases of life, and I'm breaking each one down below:

Sales: You're looking to sell 1 of 2 things. 

1 - Something new. In this case, you're a category creator. Showcasing the value add to the business is critical, if you can win a pilot and show how you're improving efficiency / saving costs / (or the ABSOLUTE best) increasing revenue? 

You've got a sale

2 - Something better (or cheaper). Here, some version of it already exists and is in use. Replacing the incumbent requires you to showcase a HUGE difference from them, whether in cost or results. Enterprises are notoriously unwilling to shift from an incumbent because of the retraining and costs involved.

Startup: I've raised over $300 million (not alone!) across 3 startups I've worked with, and the critical piece here is identifying that one champion, the person who will go to bat for you. This part is VERY VERY hard. You'll hear a hundred Nos before you get one person who'll build your round.

Venture Capital Fund: By far the hardest fundraise I've done for two reasons.

1 - You're competing against the World of Assets. Public equity, derivates, bonds, art, whisky casks (yes), gold, crypto, PE, then VC. All of these are avenues where wealthy folks park assets. 

2 - Many many champions. While a few folks will be a large part of the fund as anchor investors, funds still typically have 40-80 LPs, which means you're running a funnel speaking to 1000s of people, showcasing yourself amongst other Asset classes, then against other Funds.

Across the board, the biggest lesson I've learnt is, a quick No is one of the biggest gifts (after a Yes) you can give the World around you.

#venturecapital #startups #fundraising

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Red Bull. Some of us remember late night study sessions, some late night party sessions, for those of us in college ~2005-2015, we remember FREE cans.

While I barely touch the stuff anymore (espresso shots if caffeine is that necessary!), I LOVE the way the brand built and marketed itself.

For those who may not know, Red Bull is originally a Thai drink called Kratik Daeng, sold at roadside stalls, mainly consumed by construction workers, drivers and folks performing hard labour.

In 1984, Dietrich Mateschitz collaborated with the drink's Founder, Chaleo Yoovidhya, adding carbonation to the beverage while preserving the charging bull logo.

Dietrich launched the drink in Austria in 1987, focusing on nightclubs. One of the methods Dietrich used to create virality was dropping crushed cans of Redbull outside some of the hottest clubs in the city, creating a perception that all the 'cool kids' were drinking Red Bull.

Because of it's caffeine and taurine content, for a while, the drink was banned in Hungary, France and Denmark, with no marketing allowed in Germany.

The 'banned item' craze spread through, with folks smuggling cans of Red Bull into other countries for their friends.

Simultaneously, Dietrich channeled a large chunk of the brand's profits towards extreme sports marketing, sponsoring challenges and extreme sport athletes across skiing, snowboarding, skydiving, racing and more.

Today, Redbull makes ~$13 billion dollars, selling in 171 countries, with a ~46% share of the energy drink market they effectively created.

#startups #founderstories #marketing

author/headline: Software Engineer | TEDx Host | 2x Founder
text:
I'm looking for the next challenge on any continent, and I'm counting on your support

Who am I?
I‚Äôm a Software Engineer and generalist with 8 years of experience across robotics, AI, SaaS, and clean tech. I‚Äôve founded and led two startups (Robotics and Agri-tech), and I‚Äôve also worked in corporate engineering and R&D environments, so I know how to move fast and navigate structure.

What I‚Äôve done

Project coordination (Budgets up to $1.5M)
‚Ä¢ Led the full development of an autonomous cleaning robot, from concept to CE certification.
‚Ä¢ Managed product timelines, suppliers, certifications, and production.


Technology
‚Ä¢ Built hardware systems (IoT, robotics, energy storage) from the ground up and deployed them in real-world use.
‚Ä¢ Built SaaS products, handled QA, integrations, and system automation.
‚Ä¢ Led AI and robotics projects, including an AGV monitoring system and an AI assistant indexing 60+ repositories for internal developer productivity.
‚Ä¢ Experience across Python, Node, TypeScript, C++, ROS, and cloud systems (AWS, GCP, Azure).

Team Management in Startups
‚Ä¢ Built and led a 15-person team across engineering, operations, marketing, and deployment.
‚Ä¢ Managed international collaborations and vendors across Europe and Asia.

B2B & B2G Sales and Marketing
‚Ä¢ Closed $200k in sales across South Korea, Spain, and Portugal.
‚Ä¢ Skilled in go-to-market strategy, market segmentation, and crafting offers that resonate.
‚Ä¢ Strong storyteller who knows how to turn tech into business value.

PR and Branding
‚Ä¢ Built 3 brands from scratch and secured coverage in Forbes and other major outlets.
‚Ä¢ Represented startups at global tech and healthcare events.

Fundraising and Grants
‚Ä¢ Raised $1.5M+ from venture capital, angel investors, and government grants in India and Poland.
‚Ä¢ Managed project accounting, investor relations, and grant reporting.

How I can help you?
I‚Äôm the kind of person who can build, lead, and sell across both startups and corporates.

If you need someone to:

‚Ä¢ Ship complex products from prototype to production and lead engineering teams
‚Ä¢ Position products, craft compelling value propositions, and drive GTM strategy
‚Ä¢ Bridge technical execution with business outcomes and translate for both execs and engineers
‚Ä¢ Identify AI, automation, and robotics opportunities and run strategic experiments
‚Ä¢ Close funding rounds, partnerships, and B2B deals
‚Ä¢ Integrate sustainability and impact into both tech and business strategy

What I'm looking for

‚Ä¢ A senior or C-level position at an impact-driven startup that's raised or ready to scale.
‚Ä¢ A leadership role in a forward-looking corporate team (engineering, product, innovation, or R&D).
‚Ä¢ Sales, business development, or product management roles where I can leverage my technical background to drive growth.
‚Ä¢ A consulting or advisory role in startups, sustainability, or tech transformation.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Colleges in India have really stepped up their game!

It was a pleasure to speak on a panel at SVKM's Narsee Monjee Institute of Management Studies (NMIMS) , thank you to the amazing college team that organized it and Harssh for the invite. 

Wonderful hearing the views on entrepreneurship, creating something from nothing and how to navigate India from Achal Mittal and Abhishek Daga .

Key takeaways: 

Patience, patience, patience: Building something real takes time, it can't be rushed, even with money thrown at it

Culture: In the beginning, Founders are just trying to survive, juggling salaries, vendor payments and navigating the maze of Indian bureaucracy.

Grit: A great question came up, how do you keep going against all odds? Both Abhishek and Achal echoed the same sentiment, failure isn't an option. You put your head down, show up and keep going. 

Dhanda: Achal shared a great anecdote, when explaining what he did at Rentomojo to his to-be father in law. FIL responded, so you're a kabbadiwala? (furniture rental guy). 

At the end of the day, a startup has to evolve to a business, which makes money. 

#venturecapital #founderstories #startups

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
The Shark Tank Effect. Making Startups Acceptable.

India has an interesting blended culture, one that venerates success in Business, while discouraging all forms of risk taking ability for our young.

For generations, the Indian Dream has been:

Become Doctor, Lawyer or Engineer, preferably in the USA (followed by Canada and Australia). Engineer quickly became a euphemism for MBA (must do both)

A successful business person in the community got respect and envious glances.

Someone trying to build a business from scratch? Usually told "Beta, too risky, Beti focus on education and career".

Someone quitting a high paying corporate job to start up? INSANE!

It's important to remember that the Indian startup journey is barely out of it's teenage years, with the first advents starting around 2005.

A big driver to support this, not just the capital, but to make it ACCEPTABLE to start up, and similarly ACCEPTABLE to fail, is a show like Shark Tank.

By showcasing Founders from all walks of life, creating incredible businesses, from NOTHING, it's turned entrepreneurship from Taboo, to something Dadi is proud of telling her friends "My grandchild is building a company!"

2025 is almost up, but it's the past two decades that have shaped what's to come.

A robust domestic pipeline of Capital, VCs and Startups alike raising from LOCAL investors, run by folks who have been shaped by the past two decades of Indian Startups.

The WAVE of IPOs about to happen is a culmination of Hope, Energy and Awesomeness.

#venturecapital #india #startups

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Friday rant! If it's too good to be true? It probably is. 

A potential LP asked me how I identify or mitigate fraud. 

Aside from the usual, diligence, deep Founder relationship and evaluation, domain knowledge, I'm sharing a few tips based on my personal history. 

I was part of an extremely interesting journey called Zilingo.

Company was led by good founder pedigree, assembled a strong team, raised capital from some of the best investors in the world. 

My first week there, I left office on a Friday at 7pm, only to get a call to go back urgently. 

We weren't going to make our projections for the month (at that time we were an e-commerce marketplace).

My first reaction is, sure, it happens, you can't whack every number out monthly.

Incorrect, as per company policy. 

Despite us being a marketplace, I created an apple watch store, then had to go to various showrooms the next day, buy 100 apple watches and sell them at a discount. 

So we could hit the numbers. So that every month was a ~10% growth. 

The biggest red flag for me is very high consistent growth, at a pace that's abnormal.

Business just doesn't work like that.

If it looks like a rabbit but quacks like a duck, it's probably a duck. 

#venturecapital #rant

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Fundraising for Science Projects versus Fundraising for a Business

I chatted with a Founder yesterday. They were highly technical, with a strong team around them to build in the Biotech space.

They had gone to the market for a fundraise earlier in the year, were rejected and they came to me for advice.

Version 1: Preventative care, focused directly on consumers. 

Rejected by funds. Very clear pushback here on preventative diagnostics and the Indian consumer. Unless you can find a way to bundle it with other tests/services (selling to Diagnostic Labs and Hospitals), very hard.

Version 2: I spent twenty minutes on the call before I paused the Founder and said "You've shared 3 different products you want to build, not told me how you're going to take them to market, how you're going to make money and, MOST IMPORTANTLY, what's your edge?"

After a lot of back and forth questioning, I understood what they were trying to do.

They were approaching this like a PhD research grant, with a 4 year horizon to hit the market, unclear on the proven efficacy (can their test reduce mortality or risk of disease, by what percentage, and compared to what existing test costs)

My feedback: 99% of investors will not understand this, nor will this excite the 1% who do.

When asked for an example of a great pitch, I shared one of my personal portfolio, Lilac Insights.

Referred by the Founders of Wellness Forever, Lilac's pitch, despite being in a complex field, was crystal clear.

'We have licensed one of the best US tests for non invasive pre-natal (before birth) diagnostics. We've also licensed similar tests for oncology (cancer). These tests are genomic, basically testing for mutations in DNA, then our panel of experts can share suggestions on treatment path.

We will sell the tests in bulk to hospitals, so we have very low distribution costs, while assembling the best team of clinical geneticists with us, ensuring competitors will have to settle for lower talent.

Over time, we will use these hospital relationships to sell additional tests, some self developed by us using funding+revenue'

Our goal is to lower the costs of these tests so that more and more of the country can access them'

This pitch? Takes a complex topic and simplifies it (since most investors are NOT biotech grads).

Tells me exactly how they are going to distribute, control costs.

Chosen sectors tell me there's going to be no reluctance for spending, India will spend anything on childbirth and health, and humans generally to treat cancer.

Tells me their edge (best talent), let's me infer a second edge, which is the data and AI uses.

Tells me of the future, leveraging existing distribution to launch more tests, some proprietary.

Folks, ERASE the word 'Startup' and replace it with Business, since that's what you NEED to showcase to investors.

PS: Addressing the inevitable rage rants, YES, India has VERY low amounts of capital for R&D.

#venturecapital #funding

comments.Comment:
Such an important distinction and one I see all the time when coaching biotech founders. Many approach investors as if they‚Äôre submitting a grant proposal focused on data, hypotheses, and long-term potential instead of communicating like business leaders.
Investors don‚Äôt fund exploration; they fund execution. What separates the ones who get a ‚Äúyes‚Äù is clarity, on how the science translates into value distribution, cost advantage, and scalability.
In my experience, the turning point often comes when founders start thinking like storytellers, not scientists. The story isn‚Äôt about what‚Äôs in the lab, it‚Äôs about how that science moves through the market and impacts lives. That‚Äôs when the conversation changes completely.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Farming Vs Hunting    |    Retention Vs Acquisition    |   Boring Vs Fun?

Very often, Founders, sales and srowth leads, young professionals, all get caught up in the excitement of NEW. 

Get a NEW lead. A NEW customer. A NEW channel. 

I sat down with all sorts of sales folks (from BigTech like Meta, Google and Stripe to other VCs raising funds) and a few points stand out:

Numero Uno: It is significantly faster and easier to upsell an existing customer, than to go through the Song & Dance of convincing a new one. 

II : To be able to upsell, you MUST build a strong regular cadence with your customers. Ideally with one core Person In Charge / Relationship Manager (PIC/RM), along with contact points for other support (technical, legal).

The ideal from US bigtech perspective (for large clients mind you) is weekly soft touches (hey everything ok?), monthly scheduled calls (intro new feature) and quarterly business reviews. In a QBR, you compile data, showcasing their usage, highlighting any changes you feel could benefit their business (using your products of course).

Trois : Existing customers are your BEST sources of new features, they will help build your product pipeline. Identify the power users, folks who LOVE your product. Asana has done a brilliant job with this, creating Asana Ambassadors within customer orgs.

2¬≤ : Here's where you can use a level of 'free' or a discount without hurting your brand. Offering an existing client a 3 month trial of a new feature, or a 1 year discount on the latest product you've launched, allows you to test and upsell without hurting your pricing power for new customers.

This doesn't mean you stop looking for new customers! But it's important to prioritize, focusing on retention + upselling before chasing growth

#venturecapital #saas #startups #growth

comments.Headline: Entrepreneur | Founder @ Adventroz ‚Äì Travel. Culture. Legacy. | Helping Founders Build Smarter With Tech, Marketing & Capital
comments.Comment:
Most startups die not because they fail to acquire, but because they fail to retain.
Everyone wants to scale, but few realize scale without retention is just churn in disguise.
Retention is proof of product-market fit. Acquisition is proof of marketing fit.
If your old customers aren‚Äôt buying again, your funnel isn‚Äôt growing, it‚Äôs leaking.
The best founders I‚Äôve met treat existing users like investors: they keep them updated, make them feel part of the journey, and always deliver more value than expected.
The day your existing customers start bringing you new ones, that‚Äôs when you‚Äôve actually achieved growth.

comments.Headline: milliGOLD | RSR Innovations
comments.Comment:
People often confuse upselling models with supermarket models. (More common in B2C)

Just because you have users using your product, through a digital / offline / omni channel, does not mean you can sell them new categories or even new emotional values within the same category.

Examples : Selling Insurance or personal loan to a saving customer is not upselling, it is new sales which is as costly (or costlier).as acquiring a new customer for that category. It is more easy to sell fashion jewellery (5k to 20k) to a micro saving customer than sell them cultural jewellery (1 lac to 10 lac). But a buy-now-pay-later only for jewellery  with average ticket size of 5 lacs is a much easier product to upsell, if your customers are already subscribing 10,000 pm on gold savings. 

Dove as a brand cannot upsell or cross sell a fairness cream and that is why the same company has two separate brands.

An MSME owner who trusts you to hold his gold balance for 20 years (for his daughter's marriage) will easily trust you to keep his family jewellery at your branch (which he can check in&out 6 AM to 11 PM), in return for working Capital credit that he can leverage for his business - even though it appears to be two completely different businesses.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
50% off! 50% off! LOOK! Our sales numbers are through the ROOF!

High fives all around! Let's do this every quarter!

Fast forward 12 months.

Our monthly sales are tanking, even though we are optimizing (read throwing money at) our Meta and Google spends. 

Disaster!

Sounds familiar? Congratulations, you've just trained your customers to:

A. Think you're a discount brand who's actual value is XYZ/2, not XYZ.

B. You've trained them to expect extremely large discounts on a regular basis, hence removing ALL incentives to buy at full price.

But I was only trying to boost sales numbers for the quarter - Typical response

Fair enough, discounts are one of the laziest ways to make this happen

But I was trying to get rid of old inventory! - Second most common response

Fair enough, take an example from Dhruv Toshniwal or Vedang Patel, who have tightened supply chains (to ensure low inventory pile up), offer loyalty discounts to existing customers through coupons (personalized instead of flashing sales).

#venturecapital #d2c #consumer #startups

comments.Headline: Investment Banking | Private Wealth | Arambh Ventures
comments.Comment:
As a consumer - whenever I see a 50% - 70% discount on anything, the first thought is - this is not a discount. It is a distress sale.

Then the evaluation becomes a matter of quality/ relevance over price discount. More precisely - is this still the right price, even after discount? Or is it better to pay full price for a better/ more relevant product?

I like Sleepy Owl Coffee in this matter. Consistent pricing, and gradual reduction of discounts. Been paying almost 20% more for the last 3-4 months, but still worth the product quality at predictable pricing.

comments.Headline: Co-Founder For Real | Ex-VC | IIT Delhi
comments.Comment:
Discounting short circuits the price vs perceived value of the product gap. 

Keeping sales boosting aside, brands often discount to liquidate aged inventory. This issue can only be mitigated, never eradicated.

The challenge is that brands don't have a separate channel to liquidate aged inventory and hence are forced to deep discount on their stores, website/app, and other marketplaces to unlock cashflow.

What we need is a destinated away from primary channels of sales, which speaks to value-focused audiences hence protecting brand equity among high-intent category consumers that a brand regularly positions to. 

About time the country builds an online factory outlet model.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Negotiation. It's a skillset that we all use, on a daily basis, from our personal to our professional lives.

It's inherently driven by one of my favourite economic theories, Ricardo's Comparative Advantage.

Do what you're best at, and purchase/hire skillsets you aren't the best at / don't enjoy doing.

My earliest use of negotiation was in boarding school. 

You're meant to learn to make your bed, clean your cupboard and generally be tidy (at an age when a lot of folks still have parents helping with this).

An admission, I'm quite messy, and HATE tidying up.

In school, I was, thankfully, fairly bright and good at writing.

What ensued was the perfect barter system, with me tutoring my batchmates, and helping them write essays/papers, in exchange for my bed and cupboard remaining spotless (my parents couldn't figure out how I never picked up these skills after years of boarding school!).

Over time, I've enjoyed learning about negotiation from wonderful books and masterclasses, one of my favourites being Never Split the Difference, by Chris Voss.

Three key lessons I've learnt:

1. Define a breakpoint - This is a point where you'll either accept what's on offer, or walk away. Don't waste time and energy beyond this

2. Human Problem - The world IS NOT RATIONAL. Humans are emotional beings, and often, understanding the human element in a transaction can be the make or break difference.

3. Win Together - The VERY BEST deals are where both parties benefit. Reframe your negotiation to show how it benefits the other side, and suddenly, you're on the same side.

#venturecapital #startups #negotiation

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
What do I need to raise a round? Who are folks who invest?

Perennial questions I get asked so thought I'd take a stab at answering them, in reverse order.

If you're looking for a pre-seed round, GOOGLE IT! Reaching out to me, when it's CLEARLY mentioned in my bio that we are focused on Series B currently, shows me you're brain dead/have done zero research or both.

VC funds spend time, effort and money in publicizing our thesis, writing LONG blogs on the stages and sectors we invest it, trumpeting it across media.

Do give it a cursory glance if you're looking to raise.

The more pertinent place where folks need help, what do I need to raise a round? Fair question. 

Breaking this down (personal views mind you):

Fundraising is a balance between Revenue and Story (read History).

If you have zero revenue? Bring a great story. 

Why am I building this? Because I was at XYZ big companies, noticed the ABC process was broken, have validated this with colleagues and managers across the industry, have my first 3 paid pilots in progress.

BOOOM. You're probably raising a round. (and YES, odds are to get to those positions, there's a strong academic background).

No Story? Bring numbers that can't be ignored.

Some rough guidelines - 

Pre-seed: This is a fairly new concept, All in Capital, ZeroPearl, A Junior VC, Eximius, Mars Shot, great folks to talk to.

No real rules here, can be zero revenue as well, though some helps. Anything up to ‚Çπ30-40 lakhs a month.

Seed: This has ranges. Yes, there are bigger $3-5 million (‚Çπ24-40 crore) rounds. Odds are, you don't qualify. This requires a second time founder (exit of AT LEAST ‚Çπ25 crore, not I built and failed, now building again), or STRONG corporate experience, along with good numbers (‚Çπ50 lakh to ~1.5 crore / month)

Series A: Rounds of $3-10 million, requires you to showcase basic product-market fit, revenue numbers between ‚Çπ1 to ‚Çπ3 crore

Series B: Rounds of $5-20 million. By now, funds are evaluating your ability to scale. Your core customers should be identified, with strong retention trends. The core evaluation here is, can this investment propel you to an inflection point of growth, creating a new product line or expanding into new markets.

Series C and onwards: Rounds mushroom from here, tweaked to give you 24+ months of runway, with a buffer. Rounds are largely dictated by two things.
Your business plan + FOMO in the market.

Note: All of the above doesn't apply to deeptech / biotech.

#venturecapital #startups #fundraising

author/headline: Founder @ Insurevision.ai | Next gen risk understanding. Improving driving. Saving lives. Using Transformers.
text:
InsureVision just made the CB Insights Insuretech 50 ü§Ø 

Out of thousands of startups analyzed, we're one of 50 shaping the future of insurance.

The timing matters.

Early-stage insurtech funding hit a 9-year low this year.
Median deal sizes dropped 35%.
P&C insurtech funding reached an 8-year quarterly low.

While the industry contracts, we're being recognized for doing what everyone said couldn't be done:

‚Üí Turning video into predictive risk models using end-to-end transformers
‚Üí Running lightweight AI on the edge without LTE
‚Üí Outperforming traditional telematics by 2-4x

The reality is simple.

Commercial fleets lose billions to crashes.
Telematics missed the mark.
Video was dismissed as "only marginally better."

We proved them wrong.

Our mission hasn't changed: unlock the power in video to end nuclear claims and road deaths. 

This recognition validates three years of work with some of the best machine learning scientists in the field.

ITC Vegas, Thursday October 16th, 11am Pacific ‚Äî I'll be sharing how we reimagined telematics using state-of-the-art transformer AI.

Recognition is great. 
But the work is what matters.

What's your opinion on this?
What's the biggest obstacle preventing insurers from finally solving the crash prediction problem?

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Friday Rant Time! We are our own worst enemies.

There's been a lot of conversation after the Wintrack Founder's allegations around harassment, and I did a straw poll amongst friends who are business owners (legacy, traditional, startups, scale-ups, all of em).

The resounding, and sadly predictable answer? Yes, this is the norm.

It's the dirty laundry we don't discuss. The garbage swept under the rug, till the rug is the size of a mountain.

As a nation, we need to come together and reject 'fast-track'. Push back when pushed. 

The funniest (and one of the saddest) story I heard, was about how there's a 'one window system' for a certain approval now. 

Which is great, ideally solves the problem! However, the approval never comes. Or gets blatantly rejected despite everything being in order.

Till the friend had to call the 'approver on the system', hear the 'request' and comply, so that the approval went ahead.

We have AI tools that can change the world.

It's time we implement them into our nation's systems, to reduce human 'subjectivity', and clean things up.

Everything is poised for the next decade (or more) to be India's time to shine. We need to remove the final barriers, and the growth will be unstoppable.

#venturecapital #startups #india

author/headline: Building Bombay Founders Club
text:
Most founders think the startup starts after the raise.

Tanishq Ambegaokar proved it starts way before.

I was at the nailinit launch last night.

And honestly? They nailed it.
The vibe. The execution. The community.

It didn‚Äôt feel like a launch. It felt like the next chapter of something that had been quietly compounding for years.

Because that‚Äôs what Tanishq has been doing ‚Äî
compounding social capital long before he raised a single rupee.

Helping other founders.
Showing up.
Building trust.

When you do that for years, you don‚Äôt launch a product ‚Äî
you launch with momentum.

That‚Äôs what most people get wrong.
They start their startup first, then try to build their network.

But the smartest founders do the opposite.
They build their network,
and the network becomes the launchpad.

Caught up with some power players who get this game ‚Äî
Arjit Johri (Marshot VC),
Avik Ashar (Riverwalk), and
Olivia Deka üîú Global Fintech Fest (The Capital Room) ‚Äî
each one proof that social capital isn‚Äôt a buzzword.
It‚Äôs a moat.

So if you‚Äôre reading this and planning your ‚Äúbig launch‚Äù‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt just build a product. Build people.

They‚Äôre the ones who make the launch land.

#founders #marketing #launch

IPO - A key goalpost, a transformational moment, where you've grown up. 

A startup no longer, you're a mature(ish) public company, with the regulatory and regular scrutiny that comes with it.

A lot's been said about India's Venture Ecosystem, and a large sign of maturity is companies achieving, and then thriving, post an IPO.

Between 2021-2024, Indian startups created around $7 billion (‚Çπ64,000 crores) in Market Cap, creating ~$3.5 billion of liquidity going back to Founders, Employees, Funds, and through Funds, the LPs (investors in Funds).

Across 2025-2026, we've got a projected $50 billion (‚Çπ450,000 crores) of Market Cap, projected to return around $25 billion (~‚Çπ225,000 crores) of liquidity all stakeholders involved.

This is a transformational moment, since it firmly cements Venture Capital as a maturing asset class, with Family Offices and Institutions from India and the World looking at India with a deep focus for the next decade.

Why is this a relevant metric? I was having a chat with a Founder today who was firmly convinced VC is sipping cocktails, laid back days and a pretty easy breezy life.

I shared a thought. A startup needs one, maybe two funds to believe in them, and back them with capital.

The average fund? Has around 40 LPs. Which means you've (somehow) convinced 40 folks to back you.

VC funds? It's our job to invest in startups, that's the ONLY thing the capital is there for.

Families/HNIs? Public equities, Private Equity, Private Credit, Debt, Bonds, Art, Crypto, even Whisky and Wine are investible assets. 

VC competes for attention against all of them.

#venturecapital #india #startups #ipo

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's that time of the year again, Global Fintech Festival. 

The size and scale of the event are reflective of the transformation that's taken place in India across the past 15 years.

From a familiar sight of 'Cash Only' at many venues (restaurants, small stores, most low-medium ticket purchases), we have a thriving payments ecosystem underpinned by world class infrastructure, through the Unified Payments Interface.

As of September 2025 (last month), UPI handled an average of 654 MILLION transactions ...... DAILY. 

France, Singapore, Bhutan, Mauritius, Sri Lanka and the UAE have already enabled UPI links, allowing seamless connections with their domestic payment solutions.

In Razorpay, we have a homegrown payments system that's comparable with global giants, innovating at a startling pace, able to work under low bandwidth conditions (notable mention to Pine Labs as well, for widespread payment solutions).

Zerodha and Groww have created widespread financial inclusion at low/no-cost, allowing folks across India to participate in our stock market, leading to improved savings and financial security.

Navi, Lendingkart, Slice, Jupiter and several more have improved access to credit (though this can be a double-edged sword).

Close to home, Riverwalk's portfolio companies Homeville Group helps make home loans more accessible and affordable, while Aerem has created an entire platform to support SMEs to adopt solar solutions, with access to financing, EPCs and equipment, acting as a 'Solar Saathi'.

The sheer energy is incredible, with folks from all over the world visiting to learn how they can participate in India's growth story

#gff #venturecapital #startups

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Highlights from recent LP chats:

It's a Marathon, Not a Sprint: India has had a HOT stock market run, till the beginning of this year.

Folks who had barely/never invested before, including large family offices (surprising right?) suddenly woke up and dived headfirst into public equities, assuming there was only one way to go. UP.

For a lot of people, this year has been a shocker. Markets can lie flat? Sectors can go down? 

Especially given the stellar performances from Korea, Germany, Japan and China's indexes.

Once Bitten, Twice Shy: Venture Capital returns for Investors in Funds aren't equal. 

Based on Prequin Data, the top 10% of VC firms returned over 35% IRR (~3.2x MOIC) across 2015 to 2025.

The next 10% returned around 24% (~2.4x MOIC).

After that, it steadily declines down to ~1x MOIC, which means, 0 returns, but capital was given back.

(anyone confused about time period vs MOIC, should remember VC funds return capital from ~year 5 onwards, and drawdown across a 3-4 year period).

Yes, returns are HEAVILY skewed towards the top. Which is where selection of Fund Managers becomes critical. 

How are they getting into the best companies, what's their right to EXIST, forget WIN. 

I Wanna Do Direct!: The flavour of the month amongst some of the younger family offices I've had chats with is they have jumped into pre-IPO, late stage investments.

The reality of the situation? Unless you're buying out the Seed stage investors, if a growth investor is selling you part of their shareholding? They have access to WAY more information than you do about the company.

I've met some amazing offices that have set up strong internal teams, using Fund investments to identify great companies, then double down with Direct investments, often leveraging Fund pro-rata rights

Overall, VC/PE investments should be looked at as part of an overall asset allocation, with a balance between risk & return.

#venturecapital #familyoffice #investing #startups

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's rant time, therefore it's Friday! A really important topic, Deposits/Advances ARE NOT Revenue!

This is a critical mistake a lot of companies make while scaling and it's a very optimistic Founder error. 

Showcasing via a few examples. 

You're a SaaS company that's got a client who's signed up for an annual plan, BUT you have a cancellation + refund option, let's say 1 month's fee as charges. 

A client pays you for a year. 

How do you record revenue in your MIS, AND how do you manage the money? 

It's really really tempting to recognise the full amount (that way mean VCs looking for ARR see a big number) as well as treat the entire amount as earned, therefore spendable.

I get it. But if you're looking to build with a real customer focus (also Ethics), it's best to keep that cash in a separate account. 

Recognise revenue on a straight line monthly basis. 

That way, if a customer cancels, you can refund immediately instead of being caught with pants down.

Similarly, you're a housing/furniture/electronics company. Client pays you a deposit. 

Over time, that's a meaty amount of capital sitting in your account. 

DO NOT use it. Ok, use ~8% of it (one month forward), to be on the prudent side. 

I've seen complaints recently against a host of companies unable to pay back a few thousand rupees of customer deposit. 

This will MURDER your credibility. Not to mention, if you eventually wind up (which happens in startup world), you're honouring your customer trust by returning their deposits.

#venturecapital #rant #finance #startups

comments.Comment: Avik Ashar while it is correct that revenues on annual contracts should be amortized monthly for a realistic picture, however most of the financing and taxation (GST, TDS etc) is done on the basis of invoice. For sectors dependent on bank debt for working capital or term loans, often the headline YTD revenues is an important metric for decision making. Similarly, for capital raising purposes, the YTD revenues (based on invoicing) flows into ARR calculations (though on deep dive, the true picture get uncovered). I recommend that one should show two sets of financials - 1) based on invoicing and 2) based on amortization of revenues and expenses over the year to give a complete picture.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Distribution beats Product, 9 times out of 10.

I was in Surakarta, Indonesia, a tiny town in the center of the country, for work.

It's a manufacturing hub, and we were there to meet one of the country's largest textile manufacturers.

They hosted a dinner for us, inviting friends who also ran factories in the region. 

I was placed next to a gentleman who manufactured sweets (name hidden on request). 

He had build his empire after identifying a simple concept. 

At Warungs (Indonesia's kiranas/neighbourhood stores), apart from some very specific sweets, most sat mixed together in a giant jar and were given out instead of loose change after a purchase.

Neither the buyer, nor the shopkeeper were very concerned on the brand, just handing out a mix from the giant jar. 

Our story hero then observed that most sweet brands did a round every 10-14 days, adding some sweets into the jar. 

He realises if he simply does a refill round every 5 days (not more, that's getting greedy enough to be noticed), he would end up with a much higher sales throughput .

He built an entire empire around this. 

There's another important lesson here though, that business? No longer exists 

With the advent of digital payments, an under the radar casualty has been sweets sales

#venturecapital #growth #startups #founderstories

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
A Founder conversation yesterday (subject for tomorrow's post) left me with an interesting thought. How do you know you're aligned with what you do?

A good method is to test if the North Star is the same. What's the one thing you want, professionally, and does it match your company?

Riverwalk Holdings and I felt that sync quickly. Chatting with Jai Sumer Singh, CFA, he mentioned that we want a Riverwalk investment to be a signal.

That Founders are strong, business is solid and chances of success are high. 

A stamp, an indicator, something deeply meaningful.

And it resonates very closely with my professional goal, the ability to give GREAT recommendations. 

Whether it's a strategic call or an investment decision, that's been something I've wanted to build towards.

The harsh sides of this mean you say no a lot.

You're very very careful before making an introduction, a suggestion.

It also means you need to be absorbing information, constantly, about what's changing.

Investing (public markets, PE, VC) is all a game of making the best possible decisions with available information. 

In this space, I like the full form of the often misquoted "A Jack of All Trades, A Master of None, but Oftentimes better than a Master of One"

(Not sure how many folks knew the full quote!)

#venturecapital #investing #startups #funding

author/headline: CEO of Superhuman (formerly Grammarly)
text:
Eat your frog first. üê∏

One of my favorite to-do list philosophies is that you should tackle your hardest, most undesirable task at the start of each day. Maybe it's hard, maybe it makes you uncomfortable, or maybe it's just something you've been putting off for weeks. That's your frog.

The idea comes from a quote attributed to Mark Twain: ‚ÄúIf it's your job to eat a frog, it's best to do it first thing in the morning. And if it's your job to eat two frogs, it's best to eat the biggest one first."

‚ÄãSo if you want to be more productive, find that task and do it first. Not only do you get it out of the way, but you feel energized for the rest of the day. Even if you accomplish nothing else, you tackled the hardest thing when you had the most mental energy.

‚ÄãSome people prefer building momentum with easy wins first‚Äîand that‚Äôs another great tactic‚Äîbut for me, the frog method is so much more effective.

‚ÄãI have a column in my Coda to-do list called ‚Äúfrog‚Äù with a little frog emoji next to the task. Just identifying it makes a difference; that's the one I put off yesterday, the one that requires extra activation energy today.

The quote finishes with, ‚Äúand nothing worse will happen to you for the rest of the day.‚Äù As gross as this analogy is, it is a great mindset hack.

‚ÄãHere‚Äôs my Coda doc with all my thoughts on productivity philosophies, which includes a to-do list template for tackling your frog first: https://lnkd.in/gfD9xAu7

comments.Comment:
Eating frogs is great advice, but maybe it‚Äôs time Coda, as a product, became the frog on your to-do list.

As a long-time power user, it‚Äôs honestly frustrating to watch these productivity philosophies get shared while core product development has stagnated for years. We‚Äôve been asking for better permissions, a mobile app that is in line with 2025, basic things. Not even "nice-to-haves" anymore. Shall I mention Microsoft Edge or "Coda Brain"?

Instead, we get more metaphors and fewer updates. The risk isn‚Äôt that users stop caring, it‚Äôs that they start leaving. And that slow bleed is harder to reverse than just sitting down and doing the work.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
This is a post on H1-B visas since it's the flavour of the moment! 

Kidding, it's not directly about it.

There's a certain magic that happens when Indians, trained in India, across all education, premier institutes to smaller colleges, go abroad. 

Because our brilliance, our work ethic, our energy, is supported by an environment that allows these to thrive and grow, into new businesses or leadership positions.

I'll use a drive, from my parents place to mine yesterday, as an example. (I usually avoid driving, as that time can be used better, and it triggers road rage for me).

Observations:

- Two cops, on a bike, without a care in the world, helmetless, going the wrong way down a one way. Stopped to get chai as well, so clearly not an emergency

When our law enforcement laughs at the law, sends a powerful message

- A biker, slipped and fallen in the middle of the road (helmetless, obviously). Stopped to help, so many folks did as well, helped carry him to the roadside, moved his bike

Our spirit mobilizes beautifully to help in certain situations

- A wonderful fellow who went the wrong way, down a one way again, and yelled at me to get out of his way

Zero civic sense, we operate on a "Is this good for me" mentality, instead of "Is this good for us" as a community or country.

Enough has been said about broken roads, it's an absolute and completely visible showcase of broken systems and corruption (since relaying the roads is a source of recurring revenue, after the first windfall from cutting corners).

Chats with Founders over the weekend add to it:

- 'I was promised a startup grant but it's not being released' (have seen this in a personal investment as well, the company nearly died and had to raise at PAINFUL terms to survive, despite having qualified for a large grant which took it's own sweet time to be released)

- 'My GST number application has taken over four months and I've been told there's only one way to expedite it'

Let's not forget, taxation feels like it tells you two things:

Don't be successful
OR
Use the wonderful loopholes that exist and thrive

As an Indian, and an investor, I'm VERY VERY excited about a wave of new, fantastic talent, coming back with energy to build.

As a pragmatist and patriot, I desperately hope we prepare the soil for this growth, through further ease of business, taxation, cutting out red tape.

Great trees can't grow in a desert.

#venturecapital #startups #india
