author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Friday rant time! Please, please, please, don't max out your credit cards, take on debt or investment that's unsustainable for your family, all in the hopes that if you get an MVP running, you'll magically land VC funding.

Do it if you're looking to build a good profitable business for yourself.

I've spoken to a bunch of folks this week, ranging from delusional:

Give me $4.5 million in seed for my climatetech company at MVP stage, oh btw I have no background in climatetech, nor do I have some incredible track record

To earnest but lacking an understanding of themes, sectors and process:

I'm building Urban Company, but for Tier 3! It will be a billion dollar+ outcome, fund me.

First off, you need 1 of 2 things to get funding. Great numbers OR Great track record. 

Why, you ask? Why isn't startup investment somehow available to everyone, like air to breathe? 

It takes a MASSIVE amount of effort to raise a fund. Let's say a fund has enough capital for 20 investments. That's 20 bullets, to be fired, hoping to hit a target really really really far away, namely big returns.

Every investor is looking to maximize those odds of success, by any tiny signal or tool they can find.

For me? It's Numbers Or Story. Notice, I haven't worked at McKinsey or Google. Haven't studied at IIT or IIM. So I completely respect folks not from that track.

HOWEVER, I followed the work path. Joined a great tech company out of college (through my extracurriculars in college). Got VERY lucky, admittedly, to join, then run a family office at a young age.

Took a risk joining a Series A startup, moving to Bangkok then Singapore (low pay in the early days). Helped raise over $300 Mn for the company. 

Built my own company, had to wind it up, fought to deliver any exit possible.

Similarly, folks who've fought for SUPER competitive seats, especially if they've had to earn scholarships to afford it, gotten into great colleges, then great careers, have created a story that shows their efforts.

I know I sound like a broken record occasionally when I keep highlighting this, but it must be said.

VC funding ISN'T the ideal for most companies that need to be built. NOR do we need delivery app number 200.

#venturecapital #startups #funding #rant

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
What you say, do and the people around you, eventually become you. 

It's a well known phenomenon that you are the sum total of the closest people around you. 

So whatever habits you want to embrace, or lifestyle changes you want to make, take a look at the close people around you. 

Want to get fit but surrounded by folks who would rather get punched than do a crunch? 

Not going to happen.

The same thing applies to thought process, career choices, so much more. 

I have a vice I've not been able to shake,I love a long Friday night.

I try and spend it more and more with Entrepreneurs (startup or family biz) and I've noticed something hilarious. 

No matter the time (and the spirits of the night), our conversations inevitably go back to something business. 

Whether it's solving a problem in someone's biz, general economic conversation, futurism, it's so wonderfully forward thinking. 

Food for thought

#venturecapital #entrepreneurship #founders #habits

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Yes, Money Matters. 

Just got off a fantastic call with the CIO of a large family office. As usual, it was enlightening. 

What countless folks DON'T get is that there's no Venture Capital Fund, without raising said Fund. 

And raising? Is HARD.

A great startup? Raises seed from 1-2 institutions.

A great fund? Will still have at least 15-20 LPs (Limited Partners, fancy name for investors), though more typically ~40-50.

Key highlights from today's call?

- Global uncertainty hurts, hence FOs are wary of long term capital blockage
- Derivates and commodities are returning ~14- 18% IRR with weekly liquidity (yes this is real at high finance levels)
- INR depreciation is 3-4%, annualized, needs to be factored in. Wealth is NOT tied to India, looks for opportunities where returns are best, factoring in taxes, fees and depreciation
- Having a long track record and massive skin in the game as GPs is SOLID

A really interesting point of discussion I've had with a few CIOs with a long term outlook is that we need to create more IP and products, as opposed to cost arbitrage businesses. 

Both have their place, but technology-driven companies make up under 7% of the Indian stock market, as opposed to 15-20% globally, which means there's HUGE tailwinds to grow.

#venturecapital #startups #fundraising

comments.Headline: 2√ó‚Äì5√ó Asset Rerate | Capital Physics‚Ñ¢ ‚Äã> P&L Optics | M&A Lens: Compounders vs. Consumption Traps | Capital Yield Pricing Algorithm‚Ñ¢ | Bloomberg of Venture Pricing
comments.Comment:
The scoreboard broke when capital was treated as the product. Capital ‚â† Leverage. Infrastructure = Leverage.

TVPI only looked good because ZIRP + cloud + mobile/social created near-perfect macro tailwinds. 

Buying growth and hoping for multiple expansion worked in that anomaly but it wasn‚Äôt real value creation.

DPI > TVPI has to become the new scoreboard. 

First-principles math: linear metrics extract founder equity and leak LP capital, while yield metrics compound both.

NRR is the classic trap‚Äîbackward-looking and linear. Even strong NRR with low retention yield is a mispriced asset leaking founder equity and DPI. Retention yield is forward-looking and compounding.

When CIOs call for IP and product creation, isn‚Äôt that really a call to shift from linear optics to compounding yield systems?

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Bose. A household name. And one of the earliest examples of true product obsession, Indian intelligence and American exceptionalism.

Amar Bose was born in Philadelphia, to an Indian Freedom Fighter and an American schoolteacher. 

Growing up, he earned spending money by fixing old radios and other electronics, sparking a love for engineering.

He followed up on this passion, graduating from MIT (bachelors, masters and a doctorate) in electrical engineering.

Now with a successful career, he purchased a high-end stereo system but hated the sound quality, finding it 'flat'. 

He spent the next decade tinkering around, till he released his first product, the 2201 speaker.

It ignored MANY conventional rules in sound design, leading to critics slamming the product.

BUT .... People LOVED it. The sound quality was revolutionary, making customers feel like there was a concert going on in their house.

Not content with this innovation, Bose went on to pioneer the first active noise cancellation, enjoyed by many of us on the move today.

The company went on to build RideActive suspension systems for trucks, leading to lower cabin noise and disturbance, along with deep research into the field of acoustics.

Bose famously said "I would have been fired a hundred times at a company run by¬†MBAs. But I never went into business to make money. I went into business so that I could do interesting things that hadn't been done before".

Product obsession and customer-centricity, along with a DEEP passion for Sound, led to the Bose we know and love today

#startups #founders #tech

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
I don't usually post on Sundays but this week, was unwell for a good part of it (glad to recover in time for Ashish Wadhwani hosting us at his institution, IvyCap Ventures day!)

A really important point that came up this weekend, with some family offices who were getting to know us at Riverwalk Holdings.

A big piece was focusing on how we 'add value' in today's day and age, with every fund claiming we do something amazing for portfolio companies.

Well first off, we DON'T interfere in your day-to-day operations. Our belief is simple, if you've backed the right Founder, they are the experts on daily operations.

When it comes to 6-monthly  / yearly MIS. We're not here to police you. As a team built with folks who have built businesses, from a family or startup angle, the one thing we know for sure?

Your best laid plans can (and probably will) go awry. 

Our need to see numbers? To understand the Founder's thought process. 

Folks who are overtly optimistic, and have failed to hit any numbers projected? Will go through a hard time.

BUT! We are the folks who are here to listen, about what happened. 

Once investors have invested, we SHOULD be your best friends (with tough love). Since we're now in for the long haul. 

Anyone raising today? Ref check your investors, figure out how they are in Good Times, as well as Bad

#venturecapital #startups #founders

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
It's Friday, so it's rant time, though a really short one today.

A quick Yes or No is the best thing you can do for someone today (and going forward).

Most of us inherently know whether we want to commit to something, a purchase, a partnership, a relationship, a transaction.

However human nicety, along with a deep-seated fear of offending another person (and closing a door) hold us back from quick Nos.

As someone who's spent a large part of my life in Sales, but also running a P&L, I've been guilty of this, as well as been HEAVILY on the receiving end.

A prospect that keeps pushing the conversation to next week. Let's chat in October. Which becomes November. It's the CRM from hell. 

You can't close the damn loop but you know deep in your heart this is probably NOT converting.

So do yourself, and people around you, a favour. Say Yes, or No, faster.

Side Note: All Business is either Selling, building the Thing to be sold, or supporting these two activities.

#venturecapital #startups #sales

As a marketer who has done both B2B and B2C, a clear No / Unsubscribe helps but the absence of it is neither hopeless nor hopeful.  Thinking in these extremes is what "transactional sales people" often do - and they should - because that is their job.

And that path passes through your product, its alternatives, messaging and many unconscious subconscious emotions which the customer herself is not aware of.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
A cautionary tale. It's not all Sunshine and Rainbows.

As an investor, it's in my best interest for more people to build companies.

As an Indian, it's in all our best interest for more people to build companies.

As someone who's helped build a few companies, one blew up, one had a tiny outcome, one's growing but at a normal (not VC return) pace.

The common factor I've seen? Humans are WAY too optimistic.

The reality? Over 90% of ventures born, fail. I say ventures because ANYONE, starting ANYTHING, is a venture. Ignore the sexy word, startup.

There are NO safety nets. If you pour your own money in and it fails, that money is gone.

You WILL NOT be compensated at your previous level in the Early Stages.

If you bootstrap, you eat what you kill. It's your choice how to use profits to reinvest in the business or take home.

If you take funding, despite what many armchair warriors comment on, NO investor is letting you draw your previous BigCorp compensation. This is truth.

So before taking the plunge, factor in your liabilities. Your responsibilities. 

Someone who's solely supporting a few people in their family? Bad idea.

Either make the leap young, after 2-4 years of work ex, when responsibilities are low and bouncing back into the workforce is easy.

Or do it mid-career, once you've built up savings to cushion you, ideally with an earning spouse so there's income coming into the household. 

#venturecapital #startups #founders

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Not all solutions are created equal. 

A good solution's most important feature? It solves a deep, critical problem, in a hard to replace/replicate way. 

I've seen this happen often. 

Folks have a passion for entrepreneurship (also called masochism).

They WANT to become a Founder, so start looking for problems to solve.

Not a bad way to go about it, though my personal favourite is when Founders are solving problems they've faced during their careers.

Now in order to make money, the problem you stumble upon should ideally: 

1. Be meaningful: For any company, this means it costs a lot. Everything can be broken down to cost, so time/manhours equals cost. 

2. No clear solution: Folks have tried to apply patchwork fixes but there's no clearcut solution

3. Single point of pain: Ideally, the problem should be departmental/attributable. Someone must be in charge of it 

4. Recurrence: The fix should require your solution constantly

If you've ticked all four boxes above? You've got a solid business. 

It's important to remember that corporate sales cycles have a host of problems. 

You NEED a champion, at a high enough position, with runway in the company, to push your product through the door and into regular use. 

I'm sure every B2B sales person reading this has had a really close conversion, where their SPOC left the company/was transferred etc and the deal went ALL THE WAY back to the beginning. 

#venturecapital #startups #b2b #sales

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Taking a cue from Rishabh Mariwala's morning post, Founder Market fit is one of the key things I am looking out for.

While I deeply respect folks who've gone out to build, if you've never done it before and are trying in an unfamiliar industry, you're setting yourself up for failure.

Sharing two adages that I follow closely, the first being:

Great Founder x Terrible Market - Market Wins. Smart Founders pivot, which basically means finding a new market

Great Founder x Average Market - Decentish outcome

Great Founder x Great Market - Magic happens ü•≥ 

The second being:

The first time you build, build in a space you know VERY well. Because EVERYTHING else is against you. We ARE a hard country to do business in.

New clients are skeptical, there's a massive trust deficit.

Payment cycles? Welcome to Hell.

The best way to mitigate these odds? Build in familiar territory. You know the first few potential customers, along with the best hires. 

You understand the cycles of the industry, along with gaps to be filled.

Build and Sell two companies (~‚Çπ20cr+ bootstrap, ‚Çπ100cr+ VC backed), then go nuts, build in anything you want.

You understand the hardest parts of 0 - 1, you have a reputation that can attract customers, talent and capital. Go nuts, solve crazy problems.

#venturecapital #india #startups #founders

Or raise money from folks in the game of patience capital & formidable belief in the sector.

comments.Comment:
Avik Ashar I see where you‚Äôre coming from, but I respectfully disagree.
Some of the most disruptive companies were built by founders with no prior experience in the industry ‚Äî precisely because they weren‚Äôt bound by legacy thinking.
If everyone only built in spaces they knew well, we‚Äôd never see true innovation.
Yes, India is a tough market. Trust deficits, payment cycles, hiring ‚Äî all real challenges.
 But those are execution problems, not vision problems.
An outsider with a fresh perspective + relentless learning can often spot opportunities that insiders are too used to overlook.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
WTF is innovation? Well, WTFund showed me yesterday! 

The team invited me to join as an external expert for a couple of evaluation calls, and I was blown away by some of the problems folks are solving.

Considering my inbox is usually filled with:
- Hyperlocal X delivery
- Consumer Brand 1000
- Super App 15000
- Give me money THEN I will build some sexy technology team

It was AMAZING to see chat with two fantastic companies (not naming!) solving real problems.

First one is building machines to allow engineers to quickly fabricate PCBs, allowing new iterations to happen in days, instead of weeks (which is reality in China today, but not India).

Founder felt the problem when they were building their own hardware, and decided to solve it.

Second, looking to fix robotics adoption for Indian SMEs, with a hyper focus on adaptability, incremental automation, cost and ROI.

Both teams come are young, having worked in their respective industries enough to understand what Great looks like, white spaces to build, and have made enough mistakes during their corporate stints (so they won't repeat those!).

They are solving in innovative sectors, with a technology forward approach, with potential for global scale, while creating a huge impact on the Indian manufacturing space.

At Riverwalk Holdings, we are very bullish on manufacturing and innovating for legacy businesses, with prime examples being our investments in Mirana Toys and Venwiz.

#venturecapital #startups #innovation #india

author/headline: Catalysing the impact entrepreneurship ecosystem
text:
So‚Ä¶ what actually happens after you get selected to build3‚Äôs Impact Accelerator?

This is a question we get asked often.

So let me break it down, the program progress flow here(the sessions/practices flow is for another post üôÉ ) - 

- Around 50‚Äì100 startups/founders are selected, from the thousands that apply, to form the final cohort.

- Around 80‚Äì90% of them go through an internal pitching round called the Zebra Tank.¬†
A no-nonsense pitch room where founders test conviction, refine their story, and spar with operators and mentors.

- From there, 40‚Äì50% make it to the Bar Raiser, where a panel of investors sits in, and we evaluate who gets backed.

- Eventually, the top 3‚Äì5 startups receive their first cheque - ‚Çπ25 lakhs from our side, plus full-stack support across product, growth, and founder alignment.

- And then comes Demo Day - where select startups from multiple cohorts pitch to a curated network of 100‚Äì200 investors.
We‚Äôve seen 2‚Äì3 CR of follow-on capital flow in from there.

We‚Äôve had founders from all over India, but Delhi, Bangalore, Mumbai, Hyderabad, and Pune still dominate the map.
And the top sectors among these are - health & wellness, education, fintech, and travel.

Each cohort is different, each startup is unique. But something remains common.
Founders building their hearts out. Solving for Impact, solving for mind, body, and planet.

We don‚Äôt promise overnight wins.
But if you're building with purpose, we're here for the long game.

Next Cohort applications are open.
Excited to see what you‚Äôre working on.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Cash flow is the King, Queen and Ace.

Whether a business, freelancer or working professional, managing your inflows and outflows of cash is one of the singular most important skills to survive (or fail).

The biggest example seen recently. I switched my Uber payments to credit card from UPI (points!!!!) and saw a noticeable lag in getting rides. 

Last night, an Uber driver asked me how I'm paying. I mentioned it was via card and he asked, very politely, if I could switch it to UPI.

He mentioned that it takes 7+ days for the card settlements to hit his account from Uber, which is unsustainable for him. 

Dmart is a classic business example of folks who understood the power of cash flow. 

They offer some of the lowest margins in India to suppliers, however payments are settled religiously within 30 days, no delays. 

This leads to predictable cash flow for business owners, along with volumes.

#venturecapital #startups #founders

Cash flow ain‚Äôt just king, queen, and ace; it‚Äôs the entire damn royal court. 

Uber‚Äôs saga proves what most founders forget: if your vendors and partners can‚Äôt pay rent, they don‚Äôt care about your ‚Äòvision,‚Äô they care about money in their hand yesterday. 

Dmart gets it; pay fast, play smart, win big. Here‚Äôs a new angle: startups obsess over burn rate and runway but ignore the dark art of crafting a cash flow ecosystem where everyone‚Äôs survival is synced. 

The real MVPs don‚Äôt just hustle for customers; they hustle to keep their entire value chain solvent and smiling. Lesson? Your cash flow game is your brand‚Äôs chrome armor; don‚Äôt let it rust.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Family Offices. A new-age term for India, but a mechanism by which European and American families have been protecting and growing wealth consistently for decades.

A big thanks to BCAS - Bombay Chartered Accountants' Society and Kinnari Gandhi for inviting me to be a part of their Family Office summit on Saturday.

Starting off with a fantastic keynote from Rishabh Mariwala, who's family office Sharrp Ventures has played a pivotal role in the Indian startup space, there were fantastic sessions across topics.

I had the pleasure of moderating one with Sachin Tagra, Anupa Tanna Shah, Samir Shah and Rubin Chheda, on the evolution of Family Offices and the advent of new asset classes available, from Public Equities to Private Credit, Venture Capital/Private Equity to Derivatives.

Anupa shared her family's evolution, from creating wealth in Commodities, to preserving and growing it through Real Estate.

Rubin, who runs Neo's  Private Credit fund, showcased the important role Family Office capital holds in supporting the next generation of entrepreneurs through access to debt capital, and how lucrative the space can be.

Sachin manages JSW Ventures, which, similar to Riverwalk, began as a Single Family Office, evolving into a full fledged institutional fund, anchored by the original family, raising a majority of capital from external investors (usually other Family Offices).

Rahul Khanna, CIO of Metro Shoes, explained how it's important to look at post-tax, post-fees returns, while Subeer Monga and Devashish Khanna explained what it takes for FOs to evaluate direct investments.

Subeer, sharing a VC perspective, suggested that FOs should co-invest alongside Funds they've invested in, ideally in sectors they have deep experience in.

Devashish, who runs a Single Family Office, explained that building teams to do direct investments takes significant effort and expense, so it's important for FOs to understand whether they are ready to commit to the cost + time.

One of the resounding commonalities was focusing on good advisors, folks who take a long term approach, instead of making a quick buck by selling every 'sexy' opportunity (pre-IPO rounds anyone?)

#venturecapital #familyoffice #wealth

comments.Headline: Strategy | M&A | IIM Bangalore
comments.Comment:
Hyperscalers are the only investible layer in the AI stack and in a way are independent of external capital.

Unless users are miraculously comfortable paying $1k for the AI app, the only thing propping up  AI is VC funding . No VC funding and the AI application layer is unprofitable, LLM layer is unprofitable, compute layer is unprofitable and the GPU layer is unsustainable. 

Although inference cost is dropping exponentially (which would mean the cost of compute to LLMs like OpenAI and by extension to the AI apps like cursor drops too), if the user is not able to pay the breakeven price for this entire stack (GPU, Hyperscaler cloud margins, LLM margins and wrapper margins), the whole game could implode :)

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Friday Rant time! Please DON'T fall for scamsters & hamsters. 

A Founder pinged me last night, saying there's a UK based family office who's keen to invest in their startup, but needed ¬£30K sent to them before a term sheet can be issued.

For all Founders out there, this is BULL***T! No real investor is asking you to PAY for a term sheet to be issued.

For those who aren't fully familiar, Term sheets are non-binding agreements. They cover all the broad terms that between the Investor, Founders and the Company, broadly around investment terms, control, equity, governance etc.

Folks, there are broadly a few sets of Investors:

Angels - Folks who have enough money to give you ~‚Çπ20 lakhs to ‚Çπ1 crore.
These are typically smaller family business owners, business execs or folks who've sold their companies

Venture Capital Firms - We're all typically SEBI registered (if India based), or registered with the equivalent in whichever country we're domiciled. The partners will have a strong track record, and the fund will typically have one as well. Easy to research.

Family Offices - Definitely an upcoming source of funds, there are broadly three kinds. Very actively managed FOs with large teams (examples include Sharrp Ventures, Capri Global etc). Slightly more understated, representing large family businesses (B2V, Ananta Capital). Very very quiet (not naming for obvious reasons), representing families who have exited their businesses/monetizing land holdings, and are now capital allocators (~‚Çπ5,000Cr+)

Common theme amongst EVERYONE above? We DO NOT CHARGE you for investing. (there will be due diligence costs, but that's to cover external legal and accounting firms, on actuals).

There are some angel networks that do charge, up to 2% to cover expenses is okayish, if you're struggling on a raise they are an option. Once again, DO NOT PAY until successfully raising.

At later stages, investment bankers lend a lot of value, and charge 1-3% for that service, again, ON SUCCESS. This is quite fair.

It's sad but the reality of the world is, there's always more demand for capital than access to it.

In the midst of that desperation, don't let scammers take advantage of you.

#venturecapital #rant #founders

comments.Headline: Founder, Visualizer, Project Initiator at Call Me
comments.Comment: A few years back while searching for investors for our wire factory, I came across an advertisement asking for potential investible projects. I approached the person and after a few telephone calls he said the UK investor is willing to invest 2 MN pounds into our business. The next day he sends me a SWIFT code for 1 MN pounds. I asked my banker to check the code and verify it. Unfortunately the banker failed miserably. On top of that the banker received telephone calls from the SWIFT transferring bank asking them to pay some transfer charges. I received simultaneous calls from my banker as well as the person with whom I interacted in the first place to get investors. I ended up shelling Rs. 80,000/- by depositing cash in the bank account as requested by this person. My banker too asked me to pay because he was expecting a big deposit through the SWIFT. The entire thing was a hoax / scam. I read many articles here and other social media about hoax, scams, government schemes. I wonder how many of those making these posts have had first hand experience like me.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Yes I was wrong. While it's important not to let incorrect decisions weigh you down, it's equally important to reflect on what led you to make the decision at the time.

Decisions are typically = Information you have X Current thought process

I usually like evaluating if:
- The decision I made given the information was on point
- Did I have enough accurate information
- Was there anything I could have done better in the evaluation

Apple is one of the few companies on the public side where I was very very wrong. I was an Apple Bear. Anti the company. 

After two years of using a Macbook (still hate the phones :P), I can say I was very wrong.

And a large part of this is due to Apple's decision making tree. Typically, for companies, every major product line has their own teams.

In Apple, there's a Battery team, that looks at ALL products.

Similarly, team for Screens, Chips etc.

I recently had a long conversation with a friend in the Battery team and it's amazing how they make decisions. 

Once they're 80% convinced it's the right call, they get samples for testing, run compatibility checks across product lines, then pull the trigger on ordering.

If they made a mistake, they reevaluate using the framework above.

#venturecapital #technology #decisions

author/headline: Partner at Kalaari Capital
text:
Dream11's exit from their ‚Çπ358 crore BCCI sponsorship deal - with BCCI waiving penalties due to government regulations - reminded me of a costly lesson I learned during the early IPL mobile rights days.
Back then, we had acquired IPL Mobile Digital rights and partnered with Nokia as our exclusive mobile partner. Everything was going well until legislation banned VAS services overnight. When we rushed to review contracts, I discovered a painful reality - Nokia had ironclad protection clauses for regulatory changes, but I had no such mirror provisions with my licensor.
Nokia walked away clean. I was left holding the bag.
The asymmetry in contract terms taught me that in regulated industries, you're only as protected as your weakest contractual link.
Key takeaways for founders:
üîπ Mirror Your Risk Clauses - If you're giving downstream partners regulatory exit clauses, ensure you have identical protection upstream
üîπ Legislative Force Majeure - In sectors like gaming, telecom, or fintech, standard force majeure isn't enough. You need specific regulatory change provisions
üîπ Don't Bank on Goodwill - Dream11 got lucky with BCCI's understanding. Most contracts won't be this forgiving
üîπ Risk Cascade Analysis - Map how regulatory risks flow through your entire contract chain. One weak link can sink the ship

The Dream11-BCCI situation shows institutional maturity in handling unforeseen regulatory challenges. But as founders, we can't rely on such understanding.
Build your contracts assuming the worst-case scenario - because sometimes it happens.

#Startups #Contracts #RiskManagement #IPL #Entrepreneurship #LessonsLearned Kalaari Capital Dream11

comments.Headline: Planting 3.5 Million Trees in 2025.
comments.Comment:
The Ovi OTA launch that Apalya did for the IPL was such an important milestone. It may not have received the attention that many of the later breakthroughs in digital did in India, but those of us at Apalya at the time know how much innovative problem-solving went into the day-to-day. I still remember when we crossed 30,000 concurrent sessions, a number we had only stress-tested for. Watching it happen live, with no dip in video quality on 3G, was a huge moment for us.

Whether it was delivering firsts for telcos, working with OEMs like Samsung and Blackberry, or building set-top box projects from Nigeria to Indonesia, each initiative brought its own unique challenges with no prior playbook to follow. Navigating hundreds of early Android versions, meeting telco requirements to keep apps under 5MB (and in one case under 1MB!!), or debugging why a stream worked in one part of Mumbai but not in another, on the exact same device, all of it built root-cause thinking and client management skills that I still rely on today. (Updating burnt-on apps in Sri Lanka...I can write a whole post about just that!)

Since this post is about lessons learned, I just wanted to share that I‚Äôll always be grateful for having been part of that journey.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Friday rant time. Investors don't take risks. Everyone wants Tier-1 background.¬†
Nobody is out there for the little guy.

Sharing a brief breakdown of VC economics (deep dive link in comments).

VC is NOT charity, it's pure financial services. The NUMBER ONE metric we're measured by (for older funds) is DPI, fancy term for how much money you've given back.

1x, shut shop and go home. 2x, better, but still bad. 3x, now you have a reason to live. (for folks wondering how young funds are measured, it's typically MOIC + IRR, basically, how are companies you've invested in performing at present).

Assume a ‚Çπ200 crore seed stage fund. Needs to give back ‚Çπ600 crore at least.
Ignoring fees and expenses, you can invest ‚Çπ10 crore in 20 companies, for 10% each.

Since it's quite clear (Fractal, Zomato, BlueStone, Nykaa) that it takes 12-14 years to IPO a startup in India, you can't wait that long (fund life is 10 years).

So you have to exit to Series C/D investors who WILL want a discount.

Assume 3 rounds of dilution, leaves you with ~5%, 20% discount, so 4% held.

Seed has ~75% mortality rate, so 5 companies left.

These 5 have to get you ‚Çπ600 crore.

At 4% held:

1 company needs to raise at ‚Çπ15000 - Just NOT happening
2 companies raise at ‚Çπ7500 - Still VERY unlikely
3 companies raise at ‚Çπ5000 - Closer
4 companies raise at ‚Çπ3750 - Possible
5 companies raise at ‚Çπ3000 - More possible
^This is also the price Minimalist was acquired by HUL, which was an OUTLIER outcome and first of it's kind for consumer startups.

The above should illustrate how hard the business is.

Hence when funds insist on backing folks with successful exits, strong corporate careers, or absent both, just a great educational background, is maximizing luck.

At Seed, there are two things that swing it for you. I call it Numbers & Story.

If you have a GREAT story (I sold my last company for ‚Çπ500 crores), you can have ~no numbers.

If you have a good story (I was VP Google India), once again, numbers are lower priority.

If you're 22, from a small town college, breaking it down harshly, you NEED numbers.

As an investor, we just DON'T ignore amazing growth. That being said, since this is a (very hard) financial business, we're looking at any and every indicator of possible success.

Experience here helps in two ways:
- Have already made dumb mistakes on OTHER peoples money
- Have a network who will pick up the phone and help you/become first customer

#venturecapital #startups #funding

comments.Headline: Building PoloPan | AI x Consumer Tech x Commerce
comments.Comment:
Venture Capital seems like one of the hardest businesses to crack. I think major problems snowball when the founder has tossed the liquidity event out of the window after getting the cheque - a major risk in blindside for funds - and the associated risks like erosion of entire investment capital/finding liquidity through other secondaries at a discount. 

A founder's need for more and more private capital erodes both capital and trust from the investing ecosystem. The ecosystem in India and the USA is entirely different. 

Being capital efficient early on + keen to drive towards a liquidity event = could help the VC maths better. 
Giving liquidity is the founder's responsibility, deciding to exit is an investor choice.

comments.Headline: CA (AIR 12), IIM-B | Co-founder @ Bharatsure Group - Powering Bharat‚Äôs insurance access üáÆüá≥
comments.Comment:
Thanks for sharing this perspective Avik Ashar.

Believe if the market is large enough (as is the case with most sectors in India) and a founder has sharp market insights with a proven ability to build teams, it‚Äôs worth backing them ‚Äî even if they don‚Äôt carry a 'VP Google India' tag.

If VCs aren‚Äôt willing to take this risk, LP capital might be better off in the stock markets, where returns are more visible.

Today, too much money is chasing 'star performers' at inflated valuations, while 'good performers (read strong operators)' at reasonable valuations ‚Äî with far greater multiplier potential ‚Äî are often overlooked. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre seeing dry powder pile up in the ecosystem.

For India to match the US and China in innovation, VCs will need to be bolder in the bets they take.

comments.Headline: Helping investors discover and invest in Venture Capital Funds | Ex-500Global | Ex-Oracle | Ex-AICGIM | Ex-IIMA Ventures
comments.Comment:
Interesting rant, but let‚Äôs be honest, you left out the best part of the VC business model

For that ‚Çπ200 Cr fund, assuming a 2‚Äì20 structure and 10-year cycle, the fund will charge ~‚Çπ40 Cr in fees to LPs
By year 4, you are already raising a bigger ‚Çπ300 Cr+ fund, so fee income doubles quickly. Not a bad business model

With this fee, the promise to LPs is: ‚Äúwe‚Äôll find the best opportunities, invest in them, & deliver outsized returns.‚Äù In practice, these returns are as mythical for most funds as unicorns

Now, if you think of yourself as a business, you actually have two stakeholders: LPs & startups. Since your revenue comes from startups (exits, upside), they are essentially your customers. Dismissing early founders because of ‚Äúlack of brand‚Äù or"story" (seriously!) feels more like lazy customer service than risk-taking.

When a fund insists on only backing pedigreed founders, it usually signals poor groundwork & a lack of conviction in its own thesis. It‚Äôs the equivalent of saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll only buy stocks that some big-shot investor is buying, because I don‚Äôt trust my own judgment.‚Äù 

That‚Äôs also how we end up with bloated valuations & overfunded darlings where governance takes a backseat, something the ecosystem has already seen.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Can we get an hour for your insights? Would love to bounce ideas off.
Please take a look at our pitch deck.

If these are genuine requests, sure, let's chat. For investments, we're focused on growth investments currently, so early stage, not going to progress.

Also, I detest roundabout tactics. When I'm selling (and sales never stops, as a VC you're fundraising/selling the fund), it's a very direct 'Hi, we're raising, I'd love to chat'.

Quick tips:

I put down everything I know about fundraising, VCs, leadership, hell my life journey down in my substack (link in comments). Read through first, then hit me up with specific questions, significantly better use of time for both of us.

Approach with a very specific ask if possible, it makes it easier than 'gain insights'. 

For an investor who ISN'T investing at your stage, chatting 50 times isn't going to change our minds, it's a fund mandate.

Send updates. Not daily/weekly, but every two weeks/one month update whatsapps (not emails, those are in a graveyard) are VERY powerful. If I think your progress is really strong, I could refer investors to talk to you.

#venturecapital #startups #founders

author/headline: Early Stage Investor @ Riverwalk Holdings | Building B2B Community @ Founders for Founders | Ex - L.E.K. & Samagra | IIT Kanpur
text:
Spotting Tailwinds: The Real Edge in Investing

In the last 3.5 years of investing, after meeting 2000+ companies and 100+ VCs, one insight stands out:

The biggest winners weren‚Äôt just backed because of pedigree founders or well-crafted theses; they scaled because investors pre-empted a tailwind before it was obvious.

The companies that became category-defining giants always had:
1) A¬†clear ‚ÄúWhy Now‚Äù¬†‚Äì some inflection point creating urgency.
2) A¬†simple, painkiller solution¬†‚Äì not over-engineered or complicated.
3) A¬†strong founding team¬†‚Äì capable of navigating cycles.

For example: 
> When D2C brands went digital, Razorpay powered payments.
> When Account Aggregators reduced TAT & opex, sachetized PL unlocked growth for players like Kissht and KreditBee.
> As banks digitised, Perfios helped define fintech infra.
> As savings financialised, Groww (MF-first) and Dhan (FnO-first) witnessed multi-fold growth.
> Busy working couples gave rise to fast commerce with Zepto and more.

The pattern is clear:
 üëâ Pre-empt the tailwind ‚Üí back a simple product solving a painkiller problem ‚Üí compound with the cycle.

At Riverwalk, we‚Äôve applied this lens with bets like Elecbits, Aerem, Fantail, Fresh Bus, MarketWolf, and Venwiz, amongst others. 

And we‚Äôre excited about what‚Äôs next: from land record digitisation to AI agents, pre-K schools to high-precision manufacturing.

I‚Äôve shared a longer piece on how to think about ‚ÄúWhy Now‚Äù and the importance of pre-empting tailwinds, with real examples across sectors.
üîóLink in comments
If you‚Äôre building in a space where a tailwind is just forming, let‚Äôs connect. üöÄ

Riverwalk Holdings Satveer Jai Sumer Keshav Avik Ali

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Wealth creation for teams. Great leaders are constantly keeping this at the top of their minds.

Recently hosted a few family business friends over, to cover a range of topics, including wealth diversification, alternative assets etc.

The most critical question from a lot of the new generation is 'how do we retain employees?'

ESOPs/Stock was discussed, but it isn't the ideal solution for a private company, especially folks who aren't walking down an IPO path, as there's no liquidity event for the team to create wealth.

One interesting idea that popped up. 

Every year, whatever profit is earned, after removing what's needed for reinvestment, put a significant portion of that into a 'Pool'. 

This means the Family is giving up a pretty large share of it's profits to this Pool.

The Pool is invested in safer assets (basket of gold, blue-chip MFs etc) so it grows ~12-15%.

If an employee leaves after 1 year, they get 20% of their 'share' of the pool.

If they leave after 5 years, they get 100% of their share, which would have also grown as the profit pool increases + increase in value through investing.

Every year post 5 is treated as a separate cohort (so employee in year 2 will be working towards a separate cohort for exit in year 6).

It's an interesting way to reward all employees for loyalty and retention.

Of course, this doesn't take away from rewards and recognition for the highest performers, but it's an additional sweetener to create wealth for the folks who helped build the company.

Thoughts?

#startups #familybusiness #rewards

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
The dangers of data analysis is you can (to an extent) get data to tell you whatever you want, as opposed to a sensible answer. 

This is largely driven by how biased you are when you select datasets, how clean/accurate they are, and how you set up parallels/interpretation.

I came across a post recently showcasing how amazing Mumbai airport is versus two airports the poster saw in Europe.

I'm all for praise where it's due, and our airport has modernized and improved processes in a very big way.

But comparing it to a Copenhagen airport, saying  we process 3x volume, look how good we are, is a bit of BS.

Pick a Dubai or Singapore, 8000 and 7500 flights a week respectively, to our 4000 flights a week, then look at processing times, speed to luggage etc.

One fun fact here is both these airports actively measure and report these statistics (easily found) versus hard-to-find data for Mumbai.

This similar fallacy often happens across businesses, where unless you measure honestly, you end up getting results that you 'want' to hear, as opposed to what you 'need' to hear.

I've once spent a day with portco Founders, ripping apart their unit economics calculations, where even they were shocked to realize an entire SKU line was losing money, where they assumed it was profitable.

What gets measured, gets managed - Peter Drucker (apparently)

What gets measured, can also be gamed - (every Asian)

#venturecapital #startups #management

That end part is so true, very few people admit it,

"What gets measured, can also be gamed"

I think the highly competitive nature in India leads you to this path eventually, especially if you stay in the game too long, rigidly (without pivoting)

I honestly think that 100% honest people don't prosper in India, the game is such,

Or you have to be around roughly 400% better (than the competition) to be honest and succeed.

People in India succeed despite their honesty, never because of it, 

there is a huge misalignment in incentives and it's so hard to fix.

Because so many people are fighting against hunger and basic sustenance. They never want to innately be dishonest, but the high competition (& population) often makes them distort a few facts here and there. Especially while playing high volume games.

Honesty and transparency is a big luxury (and premium), in the end.

author/headline: CEO, SpotDraft | Harvard Law '12
text:
I think I‚Äôve cracked why so many lawyers are sceptical of legal tech.

It‚Äôs not because they don‚Äôt understand tech.
It‚Äôs not because they‚Äôre stuck in the past.

It‚Äôs because in their world, trust is currency.

In law firms and in‚Äëhouse teams, the stakes are high. You‚Äôre not just expected to do good work, you‚Äôre expected to do right by your client. 

There are ethical codes, professional standards, and unspoken rules that demand you protect that trust every single day.

Now step into the startup world, and you‚Äôll see, accountability to customers takes a back seat.

I‚Äôve seen founders oversell features just to close a deal.
I‚Äôve seen sales decks promise a roadmap that doesn‚Äôt exist.

And lawyers notice.
They‚Äôve been burned before.

So naturally, they come to every vendor conversation with their guard up.

If you‚Äôre building for the legal industry, here‚Äôs my take:
Don‚Äôt lead with efficiency metrics and shiny buzzwords.

Lead with trust. Lead with proof. 

Show them that your customers are not just numbers on a slide, but relationships you‚Äôve earned and kept.

What‚Äôs the one thing you look for before trusting a new vendor?

#LegalTech #InHouseLegal #TrustMatters #LegalOps #Leadership

I‚Äôve been in legal tech for over 30 years, and one thing has never changed, tech used in legal workflows must uphold client confidentiality, data privacy, and the ethical standards the profession demands. comments.Comment:
This really resonates and love this take. Aligns with my own and my former colleagues‚Äô experience with certain LegalTech tools. The skepticism was less about resistance to innovation and more about what you captured so well: trust. And actually, somewhat behavioral as well.

In high-pressure environments where the margin for error is very low, minor glitches can feel intolerable. The moment a tool makes an error, the instinctive reaction is: "It would‚Äôve been faster and safer if I‚Äôd just done it myself." After one bad experience, the tool is often not used again. Once bitten, twice shy.

With so many pitching some form of automation and/or "agentic AI" tool, I wouldn't be surprised if lawyers and law firms approach LegalTech firms with great suspicion. A deeper understanding of the customer‚Äôs context and of your own company‚Äôs technology, not just sales strategies, might go a long way in building trust and winning lawyers over as clients. That said, my insight is based on limited engagement with LegalTech companies in the United States, so it may well have its own blind spots.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
If a tree falls in the forest but nobody is around, does it make a sound?

While this is an often debated question among philosophy students, late in the evening on a lazy summers day, there's another takeaway to this.

I've met a lot of amazing people and companies in my life. Several have this interesting belief that if you put your head down, build something really amazing, the people will come.

While I have a lot of respect for that silent culture, it's not how the world works.

For those familiar with the story of Tesla Vs Edison, Tesla advocated for AC currents, while Edison was the champion for DC currents.

Today, AC current has become the de facto, proving superior in the VERY long run.

In the short (their lifetime) run? Edison ran rings around Tesla, discrediting AC currents by highlighting electrocution risks etc.

While I'm not an advocate of negative marketing (just a dirty game), positive marketing and brand building are NECESSARY in today's short attention span world.

From Law Firms (who really have a challenge since they can't legally advertise) to Missile Makers, content and brand are becoming a must-have, not an afterthought.

My two cents? The less specialized or subjective you are, the more you need to build a brand.

If you're offering a service/product that many others do, then the best way to retain and grow your client base is by building a rapport, through a brand they relate to.

#venturecapital #startups #founders #marketing

comments.Headline: Startups| Strategy| Data| Tech| Product| Non Profits
comments.Comment:
You have a great point there. If no one knows what you have, you can have the greatest product in the world and no one to use it.
However, in the startup context, to my mind, in practice the bigger challenges currently are:
1. A lot of products and services are copycats, or 'cool', and whether what they solve for and how is really what the user is looking for, willing and able to afford is a question mark. So the assumption that you have a great product or service is questionable. And marketing it widely might just hasten your demise.
2. On the other hand the core challenge for startups is the limited resources: time, specialised talent, and money. . So what would be useful is to help them identify the one or two things they can do that are most likely to create the maximum impact, with the minimum possible  effort, money, and friction. And when coupled with a list of things being currently done that can be stopped - to save time, money and heartburn, and release capacity for the new, it would make for a more compelling proposition.
Maybe that's where Marketers could focus?

comments.Headline: milliGOLD | RSR Innovations
comments.Comment:
Many founders mistake high decibel "communications" as marketing and brand building. A flamboyant play boy may be successful in short term dates, but long term relationships require a different kind of approach. Marketing is often assumed to be same as pushing.. your product, your company and your narrative, but brand building counter intuitively is about increasing the pull so that you don't have to push. Get someone to get interested in you, in learning more about you, for which you should first show genuine interest in understanding them.

Brand building is no different than relationship building. And any relationship requires authenticity and honesty in messaging who you are, and what you stand for and what kind of promise and commitments you are offering and how you will stand by them.

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Luck be a Lady Tonight - One of my favourite Sinatra tracks, and a topic of great  debate and discussion, Luck itself.

I wanted to take a moment and address a couple of realities here.

Privilege is real. Someone born in a country with opportunity versus one without.

Being born healthy versus disabled/sick.

Being born into a family where food and a roof over one's head are a given, not desperately searched for.

That's the first form of luck, and one that's decided for you at birth, one that's genuinely out of your control.

The second form of 'luck' that conventionally breeds jealously or envy, is maximizing serendipity. 

This kind of luck takes effort to create. 

I'll pick an example, pre-placement offers today, even at top Unis, are brutally challenging.

A former analyst of mine (and now good friend) asked for help on how to improve their chances. 

My advice? Maximize the surface area of luck. 

Figure out EVERY event potential recruiters/hiring managers are going to be at for the next six months. 

Beg/borrow/steal the guest list somehow. 

Look up each person's name so you can match the face, for your top 10-20 prospects, read more about them, especially what they've spoken about or written publicly. 

Go up and make conversation at the event, referencing these.

In a market where some of the TOP international MBA schools are unable to place more than half the batch, my friend made it happen.

If you didn't peer at the work under the surface, you'd attribute this to 'luck'.

But there's a tremendous amount of work that goes to make sure someone's at the right place, the right time, and in the right situation to receive that luck.

#venturecapital #startups #founders #luck
